District: Benkovac, Gracac, Knin, Obrovac, Sibenik, Sinj & Zadar
Description: At least 150 Krajina Serbs were killed by Croatian forces between August and November 1995 during the "Operation Storm" offensive to recapture the Krajina region of Croatia, which had been held by Krajina Serbs. The campaign of violence was related to a conflict between Croatian and Serb forces, which had engaged in an armed conflict between 1992 and 1995.
Primary.Source: International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTFY)
Citation: ICTFY Amended Indictment of Ante Gotovina. 19 Feb 2004.

Description: A human rights report detailed the massacre of 600 Serb civilians by Croatian police and military following an operation to retake areas held by Serb separatists in 1995 (as reported by Reuters). The attacks occurred in a number of villages in central and southern Croatian border regions. Croatian forces also reportedly burnt entire villages to the ground and forced all remaining Serbs to leave the area, in effect ethnically cleansing the area. The incident occurred at the tail end of an extended conflict between Croatia and Serb-majority pockets within the country, which was tied to wider ethnic and civil conflicts in the region.
Comments: Report noted that a human rights report had listed 410 confirmed civilian deaths, but placed the actual total deaths at 600.

Description: Zairean women of Rwandan origin who were expelled to Rwanda said on Friday Zairean troops took 41 of their husbands and sons off trucks and massacred them by the side of the road.
Comments: There was no independent confirmation of the event.  No specific day was given just the phrase "last week" thus the day category was left blank.

Description: 13 people were killed and 37 more injured when Zairean forces dropped aerial bombs on the rebel held city of Bukavu . Some of the bombs hit near a marketplace in the city. No further details of the incident were immediately reported. The incident was related to an on-going conflict between Tutsi rebels, led by Laurent Kabila, and the Zairean government. The conflict began when the government denied the Tutsis citizenship and tried to expel them to their ancestral homeland in Rwanda.

8 people were killed and scares more injured when Zairean forces dropped aerial bombs on Shabunda. The bombs fell on the same day as another deadly attack in Bukavu. No further details of the incident were immediately reported. The incident  was related to an on-going conflict between Tutsi rebels, led by Laurent Kabila, and the Zairean government. The conflict began when the government denied the Tutsis citizenship and tried to expel them to their ancestral homeland in Rwanda. The rebels had seized a number of border areas of the country, and the government launched an offensive to regain control in October 1996.

UNICEF and Save the Children aid agencies stated that they feared that 50 Rwandan Hutu refugee children who had been seized by Alliance rebel soldiers from a hospital in Lwiro had been killed. The kidnapped children, all of whom were sick and suffering from malnutrition, were thrown in the back of a truck by the soldiers before being taken away. One report also noted that 60 adults had been abducted along with the children, though no mention was made of whether the adults were thought to have been killed. The incident was related to an on-going conflict between the Tutsi-dominated Alliance rebels, who sought to overthrow the Zairean government and who controlled the eastern portion of the country, and Hutus in the region. A large number of Hutus had fled into eastern Zaire during a 1994 genocide in Rwanda. At the time of this incident, the Alliance was allegedly operating a liquidation campaign to remove all Rwandan refugees from the region under their control.
Citation: Reuters 28 Apr 97 lba0000020011002dt4s06f6o; Reuters 29 Apr 97 lba0000020011002dt4t06gow
Comments: I have coded the perpetrator Alliance rebel soldiers as a state actor because the journalistic account of the incident portrayed the Alliance as a quasi-state actor. The Alliance, which controlled the region of the country where the incident occurred, was the de-facto "state" actor as no state forces exerted control in the region.

Description: A U.N. human rights report documented the killings of more than 2,000 people in the Ruhengeri province of Rwanda. Most of the victims were said to be unarmed civilians. The report identified the perpetrator as the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA). It was noted that the RPA had undertaken operations to halt a Hutu rebellion in the area, but that the mainly-Tutsi RPA had instead killed thousands of civilians in the mainly-Hutu area. The Rwandan government rejected the charge of having killed innocent civilians. It asserted that those who had been killed in its operations were militiamen.
Citation: Reuters 08 Aug 97 lba0000020011002dt8801i6o; Reuters 10 Aug 97 lba0000020011002dt8a01fde

Perp.State.Military: security forces including Rwandese Patriotic Army, gendarmerie & communal police
Perp.State.Police: security forces including Rwandese Patriotic Army, gendarmerie & communal police
Description: A U.N. report documented the killings of at least 918 people in 95 incidents in July and August 1997. The attacks were carried out by various state and non-state groups, including the Rwandese Patriotic Army, gendarmerie, communal police, former members of the former Rwandese Armed Forces, Interahamwe militia, and others. The report noted that the number of killings was significantly lower than the previous two-month period.

Dozens of prisoners died during a Hutu rebel attack on a prison in Gisenyi. The prisoners were described as having been killed either in the crossfire of shoot-outs between the rebels and government soldiers or when the rebels set fire to the prison. The Hutu rebels attacked the prison in an effort to secure the release of "hundreds of their colleagues," many of whom were awaiting trial for participating in Rwanda's 1994 genocide.
Comments: I have coded the intent variable as intent apparent but not stated because setting fire to a prison is an action which a reasonable person would recognize as likely to cause deaths. I have coded the collateral damage variable as collateral damage because some of the deaths were the result of cross-fire between rebels and soldiers.

Description: Amnesty International accused forces of the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) of shooting dead 300 people at Gatonde in November 1997, in an attack described as a "large-scale reprisal." The incident was related to an upsurge of Rwandan violence, which began in October 1997.

Amnesty International asserted that Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) soldiers had killed 539 civilians in Jenda in November 1997, in an attack described as a "large-scale reprisal." The incident was related to an upsurge of Rwandan violence, which began in October 1997.

Amnesty International accused forces of the Rwandan Patriotic Army (RPA) of indiscriminately shooting about 150 people at Gashyusha in November 1997, in an attack described as a "large-scale reprisal." The incident was related to an upsurge of Rwandan violence, which began in October 1997.

Amnesty International reported that "thousands of unarmed Rwandan civilians" have been killed since December 1997 in operation conducted by both government and opposition forces. The report added that so many people have "disappeared" in recent months that families are not even bothering to report them as missing; "disappearances" were particularly common after government forces carried out mass arrests.
Comments: Note that at least some of these casualties might also exist in the codebook as single incident codes. Which events were included in this campaign is not clear, hence the campaign identifier could not be used.

Victim.Identity.Ethnic.National.Citizens: a suspected perpetrator of the 1994 genocide
Description: Two Rwandan army soldiers opened fire in a bar at the Ntongwe commune in the Butare district with the aim of avenging the death of a brother-in-law in the 1994 genocide; they were targeting a specific individual, who ended up among the seven dead as a result of the attack (four others were wounded).
Comments: There is no indication to suggest that even the targeted individual was armed at the time of the incident.

Description: "The ethnic Albanian Kosovo Information Centre (KIC) said on Tuesday that 12 Albanians were killed by police and the Yugoslav army in Southwest Kosovo on Monday and Tuesday [25 and 26 May 1998]." The KIC's allegations were not independently confirmed. The alleged incident was related to an on-going conflict between ethnic Albanians and Serbs in the disputed region.

"U.N. agencies expressed concern on Tuesday over violence in Serbia's Kosovo province, reporting worsening abuses" that had resulted in at least 130 deaths. The deaths were related to a flare-up in an on-going violent conflict between ethnic Albanian separatists and Serb government forces in the disputed Kosovo province.
Comments: Report noted that Serb forces were attacking ethnic Albanian villages and that ethnic Albanian rebels were attacking Serb police forces. The death count I have recorded here likely includes some combatants (Serb police, ethnic Albanian rebels). I have coded the perpetrator as Serb security forces ONLY because all non-combatant deaths appear to have been perpetrated by them.

Description: Fourteen villagers were tortured and killed by Serb troops in the Drenica region of Kosovo. The massacre occurred on the same day as another in Gornje Obrinje. Both attacks were related to a crack-down on the KLA in Kosovo, and a wider, on-going ethnic/civil conflict.
Comments: KLA = Kosovo Liberation Army; Report quoted one injured survivor, which I have counted as injured, but did not state a total injured count.

Description: Serb troops surrounded the village of Gornje Obrinje and killed a number of Kosovo Albanian villagers after discovering their hiding place. A Reuters reporter had seen the bodies of 16 victims, including women, children, and elderly people. Local villagers located the badly decomposed body of a 17th victim weeks after the attack. Later, the prime minister of Yugoslavia denied that Serb troops had carried out any attacks on civilians. The attack was related to an on-going ethnic/civil conflict in the disputed region.
Citation: Reuters 04 Oct 98 lba0000020021113dua4018ff; Reuters 13 Oct 98 lba0000020021113duad01t07; Reuters 21 Oct 98 lba0000020021113dual02cn2

Description: 45 ethnic Albanian villagers were killed, many execution-style, by Serb police in an apparent massacre. Serb authorities later denied that the victims had been massacred, which was denied by Western observers in the region. In January 1999, wiretaps revealed that "senior Serb officials in Belgrade" had ordered the massacre because they were angered by the killing of three Serb troops by Albanian guerillas. The incident was related to a recent up-surge in violence and deterioration of a peace agreement of October 1998. The incident was also related to a wider, on-going ethnic/civil conflict between Serbs and ethnic Albanians in the Kosovo province.
Comments: Reports indicated between 40 and 45 people were killed in the incident. The Serbian forensic examiner later claimed that the victims had not been massacred, a claim which Western monitors in the region denied. The wiretap revelation came from a story in the Washington Post, as reported by Reuters.

Description: A number of ethnic Albanians were killed by Serb forces in the village of Rogovo. The circumstances of the incident were disputed. An international verification mission and an Albanian journalist asserted that the victims of the attack were civilians, while Serb forces asserted that the victims were ethnic Albanian rebels who had been killed during a firefight. This incident was related to an on-going conflict between separatist, ethnic Albanian rebels and Serb forces. An armed conflict had broken out in 1998 when Serb forces began an offensive to crack-down on the rebels.

On 4 June 1999, Reuters reported that "At least 24 people were killed in the Democratic Republic of the Congo when a Sudanese plane bombed a small town in the north of the country... Rebel chief Jean-Pierre Bemba told Reuters a Sudanese Antonov cargo plane on Wednesday dropped six bombs on Binga, about 1,200 km (746 miles) northeast of the capital Kinshasa.  'This town has been bombed by Sudanese aircraft. They killed 24 civilians and destroyed 14 houses,' Bemba said by satellite phone from northern Congo, adding 19 were wounded in the raid."

On 19 August 1999, Reuters reported that "...at least 200 people were killed in three days of fighting between Rwandan and Ugandan troops in Kisangani, the Democratic Republic of the Congo's third largest city. Traditionally firm allies, Rwanda and Uganda turned their guns on each other on Saturday in a battle for supremacy in the diamond-rich city. The two sides fought street-to-street with rifles, machine guns and artillery, overrunning residential areas, destroying buildings and forcing civilians to hide in their homes and basements, witnesses said. 'The minimum casualty figure is 200,' said Ugandan-backed rebel leader Ernest Wamba dia Wamba by satellite phone from Kisangani. 'It's mostly soldiers but a good many are civilians. Some families were killed inside their houses.' "
Comments: Decided to code an entry based on report that "many" civilians were among casualties.

Description: Indonesia's military on Thursday said it would send riot police into the restive province of Aceh where earlier this week security forces massacred unarmed protesters. At least 34 people were killed in Aceh on Monday when security forces fired into a crowd of protesters demonstrating against earlier military atrocities. The military says it fired in self-defence, but witnesses and human rights groups said it came without warning and that protesters were unarmed. "All of us from the military and police regret that there were victims from the army, the police and civilians," Wiranto said. He added that a police sergeant had been shot on Wednesday, and one local newspaper said he had been killed. The resource-rich and staunchly Islamic region on the northern tip of Sumatra has a long tradition of battling Jakarta's rule.
Five civilians died in Indonesia's restive province of Aceh when anti-riot police opened fire after mistaking the sound of a burst tyre for gunfire from separatist rebels, witnesses said on Sunday.
Comments: The police were especially jumpy after an attack on a military truck the week before had injured 7 soldiers.

Description: At least 20 people have been killed in new unrest in Indonesia's bloodied Aceh province, including 14 civilians blasted to death by grenades, rebels and human rights groups said on Monday.
Comments: apparently the soldiers believed the woodcutters to be members of a rebel group, when in fact they were just woodcutters.

Description: Indonesian soldiers opened fire on a church in the ravaged island of Ambon killing 24 people, the priest who buried most of the dead told Reuters on Thursday.
Comments: 50 Christians had taken shelter in the church when troops opened fire.  It is unclear why the troops targeted this church.  Fighting between Moslem and Christian groups have ravaged the island of Ambon.

Description: Reuters News reported on 9/10/1999 that "at least eight civilians were shot dead by security personnel in Indonesia's troubled eastern island of Ambon". Police reportedly opened fire on protesters trying to burn several government buildings in the island's capital. "More than 60 protesters were reported to have been severely wounded...the death toll was expected to rise."
Comments: It is unclear if the victims were noncombatants, and the incident is coded for this ambiguity.

Description: Reuters News reported on 9/25/1999 that civilians had been killed in riots sparked by a new security law and random violence across Indonesia. Reuters reports that "five protesters and a policeman were killed" but describes information about 7 civilian deaths. "Two people were killed...in Jakarta just as the riots were petering out after the law's suspension. Witnesses told newspapers a convoy of 10 troop carriers, escorted by motorcycles, had approached the gates of a hospital and fired shots randomly, killing two and wounding dozens." "On Friday, three protesters were shot dead, apparently by sniper fire, and a policeman was run over and killed. At least 100 people were injured in the violence." "In the remote, restive province of Irian Jaya...two people were shot dead during a riot, allegedly killed by police on Friday".
Nine church workers including two nuns and a priest have been shot dead by Indonesian troops in the eastern part of East Timor, Bishop Basilio do Nascimento told Portuguese television on Monday.
Comments: The victims were 9 church workers including one Indonesian journalist.

Description: Police in violence torn Aceh province have found 15 more bodies dumped in ravines near the site of a recent massacre, bringing the death toll to 71, police sources and residents said on Sunday.
Comments: The military says the victims died in a gunfight between soldiers, police and separatist rebels, but witnesses say they were gunned down after being ordered out of a house.

Victim.Identity.Political: Participants in a two-day independence rally
Description: At least 25 people died in violence during the three-day run-up to an independence rally in Indonesia's Aceh province. The victims died over a period of three days, Tuesday to Thursday, as security forces purportedly tried to prevent people traveling to the provincial capital, Banda Aceh. According to an unidentified witness, in one incident a 14-year-old boy was killed when soldiers fired at a mosque packed with thousands of residents in the Tualang Cut area of East Aceh on Thursday. Scores of others were wounded in the shooting, the witness said, adding that troops had stepped on Muslim holy books, the Koran, during the operation. The residents were sheltering in the mosque after police barred them from joining the gathering in Banda Aceh. The head of the East Aceh branch of the pro-independence Information Center for Aceh Referendum condemned the mosque shootings. But Aceh police spokesman Senior Superintendent Kusbini Imbar denied security forces had raided the mosque and shot randomly at residents. In a separate incident on Thursday, security forces shot dead two people who tried to resist their attempts to prevent them from going to the rally, according to a local journalist. Two bodies with gunshot wounds were found in a separate area. In Bireun district, four people were killed and dozens others were injured by troops in a similar incident.  In Banda Aceh a body was found near the Baiturrahman mosque. On Tuesday and Wednesday 16 people were killed province-wide, residents and police said. Military brutality and the perceived exploitation of Aceh's oil and gas reserves by Jakarta has fed the separatist sentiment.
Secondary.Source: local witnesses, local police and local journalists
Comments: The government denied the incident in which security forces supposedly fired upon a mosque and killed a youth but the AFP report doesn't mention any other official denials.  Therefore, it appears as if the government only denies one incident in a three day campaign to prevent potential protesters from reaching the provincial capital.

Description: Violence linked to government troops and separatist rebels and their supporters in the restive Indonesian province of Aceh killed 72 people in the last 18 days of February, a report said Thursday.  Data issued by the Aceh Forum of Human Rights Concerns (FP-HAM) as cited by the Antara news agency, showed that 65 civilians, four government troopers and three rebels were killed in Aceh in the period of February 10-28.
Comments: Unclear if victims were targeted or collateral (most related reports seem to identify them as not collateral).  Unclear if military or GAM is responsible for the killings.

Description: Human rights workers said the bodies of four villagers who had apparently been shot were found on Saturday in southern Aceh, while seven civilians were killed in eastern Aceh.  Rights activist Nasruddin Badai said the victims were executed by Indonesian security forces after being arrested and taken away.
Comments: Military has not commented.

Description: Indonesian President Abdurrahman Wahid on Friday cancelled a planned trip to Aceh province, where troops are poised to begin anti-rebel operations.  His decision came as police and residents said troops had shot five civilians and two police were killed near the town Wahid had been scheduled to visit.
Comments: Military did not comment.

Description: Indonesian troops searching for separatist fighters killed seven people when they burned a village on the main road between Aceh province and the rest of Sumatra, rebels claimed Sunday.
Comments: Military did not comment.  Was looking for rebels and ransacked and burned village, killing seven.  Victims not identified as civilians per se, nor as combatants.

Description: At least nine civilians including a woman and an eight-year-old boy were killed and two others injured as government troops stepped up sweeps against separatists in the Indonesian province of Aceh, residents and rebels said.
Comments: Military denies raping and killing civilians.

Description: Two days of violence in Indonesia's Aceh province has left at least 26 people dead, military officials, rebels and human rights workers said Friday. Human rights activist Muharizal Hasan said soldiers fatally shot five civilians during a raid on a suspected rebel hide-out in Keulibeut village in northern Aceh, also on Wednesday. Police arrested four villagers, including three teachers, during the attack.
Comments: Military did not comment.

Description: Russian warplanes bombed several villages in the breakaway region of Chechnya.  The Russian air force carried out attacks against the villages in the Nozhay-Yurt district, killing 25 and wounding 40 people.  A Russian Defence Ministry spokesman said he had no information about such an attack.  Russian troops are involved in attempts to crush guerrilla resistance in the Chechen region.

A representative of Chechen President Aslan Maskhadov said that 298 Chechens, mainly women and children, had been killed in two weeks of Russian bombardments.  Thousands of villagers had been forced to leave their homes as well.

The Chechen president reported that "during the eight months of the current war, civilian deaths are more than 40,000." The current war began on 01 October 1999, "when Moscow poured men and armour into the rebellious province, ostensibly to crush 'bandits' and 'Islamic fundamentalists' based there." An on-going conflict between Russia and Chechen rebels, who sought independence for the province,  had plagued the area since the break-up of the former Soviet Union. A 1994-96 war ended in Russian defeat and de facto independence for Chechnya.
Comments: There is some ambiguity regarding intent in this case. I have coded the perpetrator intent variable as 'no information/unclear/other' as the report did not provide any information regarding intent. I have coded the collateral damage variable as 'collateral damage' as the deaths occurred in the context of a military conflict. In addition to the civilian deaths, 1,500 combatants were reportedly killed during this campaign.

Description: Television pictures obtained by Reuters outside of Nazran showed a charred bus filled with bloody corpses of passengers, apparently killed in an attack.  Reuters got the footage from a photographer in Nazran, Ingushetia who said 11 refugees were killed and 17 wounded but a Chechen official said 41 people had died in the incident.   Prime Minister Putin denied that Russian forces had struck a busload of refugees.  The photographer said the bus was in a convoy of refugees heading from the village of Chevlyonnaya toward the town of Shelkovskaya on Chechnya border with Dagestan.

Although a top Russian general in Moscow denied recent reports of civilian deaths in Chechnya, it appeared the village of Elistanzhi in Chechnya had undergone some kind of attack.  A local prefect said 29 people had been killed and 62 taken to the hospital.  A spokesman for the rebels said 32 died.  Russian officials said all reports of civilian casualties were false and that troops targeted only the rebels.

Two raids by Russian warplanes left 20 dead in the Chechen town of Urus Martan.  The village is full of refugees escaping Grozny.  A Reuters television cameraman filmed six funerals and residents said another five bodies had been taken to Grozny for burial.  On the first day of strikes a Reuters reported counted six dead and around 30 injured.

Russian warplanes bombed the Chechen village of Serzhen-Yurt, killing 27 people and injuring large numbers.  The bombing was a part of the Russian campaign against Islamist rebels in the breakaway region of Chechnya.  A Russian defense ministry spokesman refused to comment on the attack.

A Chechen official said 40 people died when a column of refugees came under fire from Russian aircraft.  40 refugees died and about 100 were wounded when their 20-car convoy came under fire near the village of Shaami-Yurt, west of Grozny.  The refugees were returning to Chechnya after finding the border closed with the adjoining region of Ingushetia.  The Russian military denied its forces had attacked a convoy of refugees and said warplanes had attacked a column of trucks carrying Chechen fighters.

The BBC quoted villagers as saying that Russian troops had killed 41 civilians in a rampage through a village near Grozny, Alkhan-Yurt.  Russia strongly denied the report that troops were fighting peaceful populations.  Several residents gave similar accounts of the killings, although the BBC admitted it had seen no physical evidence.  Local witnesses said that soldiers rampaged through the village stealing and killing people, even throwing grenades into cellars knowing that civilians were sheltering there.  A local official said he and his bodyguards had detained the Russian colonel and his deputy whose men had carried out the attacks and handed them over to Russian authorities. Russian prosecutors say there is no evidence soldiers killed civilians and the victims were probably murdered by Moslem rebels hoping to pin the blame on Moscow.  The Russian prosecutor said the villagers were killed when fighting between the army and the rebels was long over and federal troops were no longer in the area.

A large number of civilians were reported to have been killed by Russian forces in the Chechen village of Katyr-Yurt. The highest reported death toll was 363 villagers and refugees killed. The deaths occurred when "the Russians bombed the village and attacked a convoy of refugees fleeing in cars flying white flags." The entire village was reportedly decimated by the Russian attack. Russian officials denied that its forces had been involved in systematic abuses and that mass graves had been found in Katyr-Yurt. This incident was related to an on-going, militarized conflict between Russian forces and Chechen rebels, who sought independence for the province. A 1994-96 war in Chechnya ended in Russian defeat and de facto Chechen independence. Russia launched a second war against the rebels in October 1999.

Human Rights Watch asserted that 62 Grozny civilians had been killed by Russian troops in the Aldi district of the Chechen capital. The killings appeared to have occurred when civilians returned to the Chechen capital Grozny after Chechen rebels retreated from the city and fighting between rebels and the Russian military had died down. Russian troops were also reported to have demanded money in exchange for sparing civilians' lives, looted and burned down civilian homes, and raped at least two women. Medicins du Monde also documented the event. Moscow, however, denied that its forces had "carried out systematic abuses." This incident was related to an on-going, militarized conflict between Russian forces and Chechen rebels, who sought independence for the province. A 1994-96 war in Chechnya ended in Russian defeat and de facto Chechen independence. Russia launched a second war against the rebels in October 1999.
Secondary.Source: Human Rights Watch, Medicins du Monde
Citation: Reuters 06 Feb 00 lba0000020010821dw260ay2n; Agence France-Presse 23 Feb 00 afpr000020010803dw2n00s3t; Reuters 23 Feb 00 lba0000020010821dw2n06mt9

Description: "Six civilians were killed and others were wounded Friday in the Chechen capital Grozny during a gun battle between rebels and Russian troops." This incident was related to an on-going, militarized conflict between Russian forces and Chechen rebels, who sought independence for the province. A 1994-96 war in Chechnya ended in Russian defeat and de facto Chechen independence. Russia launched a second war against the rebels in October 1999.
Comments: There is some ambiguity regarding intent in this case. I have coded the perpetrator intent variable as 'no information/unclear/other' as the report did not mention any details regarding intent. I have coded the collateral damage variable as 'collateral damage' as the deaths occurred in the context of a military operation. I have coded the perpetrator identity variable as BOTH 'State Perpetrator: Russian military' and 'Non-state, internal, no state sanction: Chechen rebels' because the report did not specify whose bullets in the gun battle had killed the civilians.

Perp.State.Military: Chechen rebel members of the Russian OMON paramilitary force
Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: Chechen rebel members of the Russian OMON paramilitary force
Description: A number of civilians were killed and injured when a car bomb was detonated near a mosque in the Chechen village of Alkhan-Yurt. Local officials placed the casualty count at 22 dead and 52 injured, while a Russian official spokesperson stated that only 16 had died and 20 were injured. Police believed that four men, at least one of whom was a member of the Chechen branch of Russia's OMON paramilitary, had perpetrated the attack. This was taken as an indication that, "the rebels are trying to enter the ranks of the Chechen police." The report connected this attack to an on-going conflict between Russia, which sought to retain control of the Chechen province, and Chechen separatist rebel forces.  A 1994-96 war in Chechnya ended in Russian defeat and de facto Chechen independence. Russia launched a second war against the rebels in October 1999.
Citation: Agence France Presse 09 Dec 00 afpr000020010803dwc90552z; Agence France Presse 10 Dec 00 afpr000020010803dwca056h9

Disappearances: 16 of the dead were last seen when Russian forces abducted them
Description: Human Rights Watch urged the UN to investigate a mass grave of 51 bodies found in Dachny, Chechnya.  Of the 19 victims identified, 16 were last seen as Russian federal forces took them into custody.  Russian authorities claim that their investigation proved that federal forces were not involved in the killings roughly around the month of February. The Chechen prosecutor insisted that the identified people were civilians.   The Russian authorities claimed that the grave had been dug by Chechen rebels because some of the victims were wearing foreign-made military uniforms and the time of death varies from 2 to 6 months prior to the discovery of the grave.  In addition, only rebels dig such graves according to the Russian prosecutor.  It's hard to say which side was responsible for the killings and to be sure that all 51 were civilians/noncombatants.
Comments: The victims could have been combatants but the Chechen prosecutor insists they were civilians

Description: According to witnesses and police, at least five civilians were killed when they got caught in the crossfire during a shootout between Chechen rebels and the Russian military.  But the Interfax news agency and state-run RTR television, citing police, described the attack by a rebel assassination squad.  They said gunmen wearing camouflage clothing shot a deputy head of the village administration, a policeman and three other people.  Four people were hospitalized with wounds.
Primary.Source: Both Associated Press Newswires and Interfax News Agency had different versions of the story
Comments: If the Interfax and RTR story is correct, only four civilians died in the fighting because one of the victims was a police officer, but the story's lead says "five civilians were killed"

Description: Russian troops killed around 10 civilians during a search operation in the Chechen village of Alkhan-Kala.  Dozens were also injured.  Witnesses said almost 100 people were arrested.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: random, perhaps suspected involvement with Chechen rebels
Kidnappings: arrested 117 people, five found murdered but eight still missing
Description: Russia's only deputy representing breakaway Chechnya said that federal troops had murdered at least five civilians in one village during a wave of "cleansing" operations launched in the republic.  The deputy, who has previously been pro-Moscow, said troops poured into the village and arrested 117 people.  Five people were later found murdered and eight others are still missing, while the rest have been released.  Officials in the region have expressed outrage at the troops' conduct.

Kidnappings: Allegations that a 17-year-old was kidnapped while tending a herd of cattle and his bullet-riddled body was sent back to his family
Description: The Russian human rights group Memorial alleged on their web site that nine civilians in the southeastern town of Alleroi were shot and killed during a nine-day operation by the Russian army.  The group also alleged that federal troops kidnapped a 17-year-old boy who was tending a herd of cattle.  They said his bullet-riddled body was sent back to his family five days later by Russian soldiers.  The Russian government denied these allegations.
Comments: It's unclear whether the nine civilians killed includes the death of the kidnapped boy or whether his death would bring the death toll to 10

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: random, riding a minibus suspected to contain rebel guerrillas
Description: According to Chechen leadership, six Chechen civilians were killed and several others wounded when Russian troops fired on a minibus near the town of Argun, east of Grozny.  The minibus was passing a control post, on its way to Grozny, when federal troops hunting rebel guerrillas opened fire on the vehicle.

Russian forces fought Chechen rebels in an eastern village, Tsotsin-Yurt, for six days in an operation to flush rebels out of the mountainous region.  Ten civilians who were caught in the crossfire between the two sides were killed.

Victim.Identity.Random.Unknown.Unclear.O: Random villagers caught between government and rebel fighting
Description: Russian troops launched a special operation against Chechen rebels in the villages of Shalazhi and Gekhi-Chu that has killed 32 rebels but resulted in 11 civilian casualties as well. The fighting broke out after rebels reportedly attacked an Interior Ministry checkpoint and multiple other targets after that.  Most of the fighting in the campaign has taken place in forested areas surrounding the villages and death resulted from crossfire or the dropping of bombs by helicopters.

Mass.Detentions: Rebels took hostages attending the theatre
Description: Chechen militants seized a theater in Moscow, took more than 800 hostages and claimed that they would blow up the building if the war in Chechnya was not terminated.  To prevent the militants from detonating more than 100 pounds of explosives rigged to the theater, Russian forces stormed the theater and used an opiate-based gas to knock out the attackers.  Authorities insist that all the 41 militants were killed and none were allowed to escape.  Of the 128 noncombatant deaths, five of the victims were killed by gunshots but the rest died because of the gas.  Sixty-seven of the freed hostages still remained in hospitals at the time of the report and five were in grave condition.
At least 10 civilians have been killed during a military assault on Muslim kidnappers in the southern Philippine island of Jolo, a survivor fleeing the fighting said Wednesday.
Comments: An eyewitness said that 10 civilians had been killed during the assault, however did not say whether they were killed by the kidnappers or the military.  The official death count by the Philippine government is 4 civilians.

Description: Over 30 civilians, six Guinean soldiers and an unknown number of rebels were killed in attacks by gunmen on Thursday and Friday in the southern Guinean town of Nongoa.  The attack was perpetrated by gunmen who Guinea says are helped by Liberian forces and Sierra Leonean rebels.  Other civilians were wounded, while thousands of refugees and local Guineans had fled their homes during the fighting.
Comments: It is unclear from content and context of the article who the intended targets of the attack were.  It is possible that the civilian deaths were a case of collateral damage, but there was not enough evidence to support that conclusion.

Description: Burundi villagers said government troops killed 10 civilians including three women in an offensive against ethnic Hutu rebels this week in hills surrounding the capital Bujumbura.
Comments: The army denied the charge but said armed action in the African country's civil war inevitably put civilians at risk.

Description: At least 13 civilians have been killed during military operations in western Burundi, a private radio station reported Friday.
Comments: The government, which said the two soldiers were only injured in the ambush, confirmed the military has been conducting searches of the village and surrounding area since Wednesday, but denied that any civilians had been killed, the radio report said.

Description: "At least 60 people have been killed in Burundi during more than a week of fighting between the army and rebels near two towns outside Bujumbura, the capital, witnesses said Friday.  The fighting began around noon on Jan. 15 near Kanyosha, about 8 kilometers (5 miles) from Bujumbura, when army helicopters began strafing fields outside the town, said a resident who witnessed the attack but did not want to be identified because he feared for his safety....  At least 24 people were killed in the cross fire between the army and rebels since the fighting began, they said."
Comments: The lead indicates that 60 deaths occurred, and 24 of the victims died in crossfire.  This indicates that the rest of the deaths were combatant deaths, but does not assert that the 24 were noncombatants.

Description: "Two weeks of attacks on the ground and from the air by the Burundian army have left more than 400 civilians dead in the hills around the capital, a rebel spokesman said Friday.  The claim could not be independently verified because fighting in the area continues and the army restricts journalists from visiting combat zones.   Lt. Gelase Ndabirade, a spokesman for the Forces for Defense of Democracy, said the army has been attacking rebel strongholds near the capital, Bujumbura, for two weeks using ground troops and helicopters firing missiles and dropping bombs."
Comments: These killings happened as the government was attacking rebel strongholds using troops and helicopters firing missiles and dropping bombs.

Description: " A rocket-propelled grenade fired by the army hit a house in southeastern Burundi, killing eight people from the same family, including six children, a rebel official and an independent radio station said Wednesday.  Two parents and their children were trying to hide from fighting between the army and Hutu rebels when the grenade struck their house in Mutamba commune, 18 kilometers (11 miles) southeast of Bujumbura, on Monday, African Public Radio said."

Perp.Non.State.Ideological: National Liberation Forces (FNL) - a Hutu rebel group
Perp.Non.State.Ethnic: National Liberation Forces (FNL) - a Hutu rebel group
Description: "Sixty people have been killed in two days of fighting between Burundi's army and rebels outside the capital, while 15,000 have fled the combat zone, a private radio station reported Thursday.  Army spokesman Colonel Augustin Nzabampema told AFP there had been fighting in the Nyabiraba district, 20 kilometres (12 miles) from Bujumbura, but neither confirmed nor denied the casualty figures given by Radio publique africaine....  'If people have been killed, they are rebels because this sector has been deserted by its inhabitants for a long time,' Nzabampema said."
Comments: It is unclear how many of the 60 reported deaths were actually noncombatants.  The report only states that some of them were women and children, indicating that these are at least partially noncombatant deaths.  The contestations coded in this case arise from statements from a state official claiming that any deaths occurring in the region were rebel deaths, and that any innocents have left the region long ago.  He is thus not contesting the deaths themselves, but the combatant status of the dead.

Description: "Twenty-seven Burundian civilians were killed in crossfire during clashes between the army and rebels in the hills around the capital Bujumbura on Monday, a privately owned radio station reported.  The radio quoted local people as saying the victims were caught in the fighting while on their way to market in the capital. There was no independent confirmation of the report."
Comments: These dead were killed in crossfire between the rebels and the government.  The rebels are reporting these deaths and are laying blame on the government for attacking the rebel positions when civilians may be easily killed in the process.  The AP reports 28 dead.

Description: "Thirty-eight people were killed April 6 after soldiers surrounded a house in the northwestern village of Gihanga, Bubanza Province, thought to be harboring rebels, the Burundi Human Rights League said in a statement.   The occupants opened fire, triggering fierce fighting that killed 29 civilians, seven rebels from the Hutu National Liberation Forces (FNL) and two soldiers, the group said, adding that at least 20 houses were damaged or set ablaze."

"Five civilians were killed Saturday during clashes between government troops and rebels at Ruziba south of the capital Bujumbura, official sources and witnesses said.  'Rebels from the National Liberation Forces (FNL) attacked an army position, and five civilians were killed in the attack,' a local official told AFP.   Several people who had fled the area added the army had blindly opened fire in response to the attack, after having lost some soldiers from there own ranks, a version of events disputed by the military."
Comments: The exact perpetrators of these killings are unclear, although the army seems to have been guilty of indiscriminate fire.  Both combatants in this battle were listed as the perpetrators.

Description: Army troops have killed five civilians in retaliation for three separate rebel attacks in which two soldiers and four civilians died, witnesses said Wednesday.
Comments: But army officials said no civilians had been killed by the army in Ruziba.

Description: Two army offensives just outside Burundi's capital has left 24 civilians dead, among them old women and small children, survivors said Thursday, as negotiators from both sides prepare for peace talks next week.
A government official in Kabezi, Emmanuel Baragiye, said the 18 victims "were all civilians who had just left mass and were caught in the crossfire of the fighting between the army and the rebels."
Comments: Army spokesman Augustin Nzabampema denied the claims that government troops had killed civilians.

Description: Fighting between Hutu rebels and the Tutsi-dominated army in hills surrounding Bujumbura left 30 civilians dead and forced 1,500 others to flee their homes, an independent radio reported Tuesday.
Comments: Capt. Manirakiza, an army spokesman, said no civilians were killed in the fighting.

Description: Vieira de Mello referred in his letter primarily to the mass killing of 173 mainly civilians which took place on September 9 in the central town of Itaba in the province of Gitega.
Comments: Last month, the army described the Itaba massacre as a result of "errors of judgment" and said an enquiry had been set up.

Description: Representatives of Iteka in Kanyosha, 20 kilometers (12 miles) south of Bujumbura, had counted the bodies of 10 adults and six children. He said some had been shot and others had been burned in their homes.
Secondary.Source: Iteka human rights organization in Burundi

Description: "Eight civilians were killed on Monday by Burundi's Tutsi-dominated army in a reprisal strike in a Hutu- dominated neighborhood of the capital, Bujumbura, witnesses said.  Local authorities denied the witnesses' version of events.  Witnesses said the incident took place after a group of unidentified people stole a gun from a paramilitary policeman, who managed to run away.  Army soldiers arrived, surrounded the district of Taba, and then gunshots were heard, several dozen witnesses told AFP.  'The soldiers killed a person from the documentation service (Burundian secret service), as well as three construction workers building a house and a man and his three children,' said one witness.  The killings were confirmed by a source in the local administration, who asked not to be named.  Jean de Dieu Niyongabo, a local government official, said rebels dressed in civilian clothes had opened fire on soldiers on a patrol, 'who then returned fire.'"
Comments: The government disputes the reported eyewitness version of the facts, saying that the "civilians" who were killed were actually in the vicinity of plainclothes rebels, whose fire the rebels were returning, thus claiming collateral damage.  The civilian version of the facts is what I reported because they seem more likely and were corroborated by an anonymous source in the local government.

Description: On Monday, "fighting between the rebel National Liberation Forces, or FNL, and government soldiers killed eight people and injured two others, said Jean de Dieu Niyongabo, a local government official.  The fighting began in the Taba neighborhood of Bujumbura after rebels captured a government soldier, Niyongabo said.  The soldier escaped and alerted other soldiers in the area, he said.  A witness, who declined to be identified, said all those killed were civilians."
Comments: There are two perpetrators in this case, because the civilians were killed in the crossfire from a battle between government forces and the FNL.  An eyewitness account identified all the dead as civilians.  The word "crossfire" does not appear in the article, and although it is presumed that the weapons used were firearms, there is no concrete indication of that.

Description: "A human rights group Friday accused Burundi's army of killing dozens of civilians, raping women and burning and looting hundreds of houses last month as the government and rebels were negotiating to end the central African nation's 9 1/2-year civil war.  New York-based Human Rights Watch said the attacks took place in Mwegereza in the eastern province of Ruyigi on Jan. 19 after government soldiers had cleared rebel fighters from the area.  'Possibly more than 80 civilians' were killed by army soldiers including a pastor and 16 women and children, the group said in its report....  Some of the dead were shot, while others were clubbed or stabbed with bayonets, the report, based on eyewitnesses accounts, said....  Army spokesman Col. Augustin Nzabampema acknowledged that there had been fighting in the area, but he said the army had not deliberately killed civilians....  The rights group also accused rebels of the largest faction of the Forces for the Defense of Democracy, or FDD, of killing and raping civilians, as well as enlisting children into its fighting force.... Burundian soldiers also raped women from the area, burned and pillaged homes, and refused to allow people who fled to return to gather harvests and work their fields, the paper said."
Comments: The weapons used in this atrocity are both firearms and primitive weapons.  The event is contested because the government troops deny any intentional killings of civilians.  There is a range reported because between the two accounts there could be anywhere from 32 to more than 80 deaths.  80 is the number recorded because that estimate appeared in both accounts.  While the accusations are mainly directed at the Burundian military, the report adds that the rival FDD may also have killed civilians, raped women, and enlisted children into their forces (this last charge prompted the citation under "other tactics" category -- there is no indication that the army was involved in such activity).  The charge that the Burundian army refused to allow workers return to the fields constitutes the denial of food aid to the population.  The burning of domiciles constitutes the employment of "scorched earth tactics."

Description: "Burundian rebels killed four soldiers and the army killed 13 civilians in separate incidents, officials said Thursday.  13 civilians - nine women and four men - were killed between Friday and Saturday when the army shelled their village outside of Giheta, a central town 03 kilometers east of Bujumbura, said a local official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.  Col Augustin Nzabampema, the army spokesman, said soldiers believed they were shelling a position held by the rebel Forces for the Defense of Democracy, or FDD - the country's other main Hutu rebel group.  He could not say how many people died during the shelling."
Comments: The weapons used in this killing are "heavy weapons" because the news article described the incident as a "shelling."  Also, the admission that the killing was a mistake allowed me to code the perpetrator intent as "killing intentional, civilians not intentionally targeted."  Also, the admission by the army of this mistake has been interpreted as a regret on behalf of the perpetrators.

Description: "Fighting between Burundi's army and Hutu rebels has uprooted 12,000 people in recent days, swelling a near half a million-strong population of homeless and needy in the tiny African country, officials said on Thursday.  The Tutsi-dominated army has said it has killed about 100 Hutu rebels since it began an offensive in northwest Bubanza province on May 5 against the Hutu Forces for the Defence of Democracy (FDD), the main rebel group in a decade-old civil war.  The FDD, fighting to end the political dominance of minority Tutsis in the country of 6.5 million, denies it lost fighters in the clashes and said any dead were civilians killed by the army."
Comments: This code is considered a "Rumor/Allegation" because the alleged perpetrators deny that civilians were killed in this campaign, claiming that they killed about 100 Hutu rebels during the offensive.  The Hutu Forces for the Defence of Democracy (FDD) denies these claims saying that the Tutsis have not killed and FDD fighters, but only civilians.  The report backs neither side of the story, so I coded the accusation and denial here.

Description: "The army killed 23 Hutu rebels during fighting in central Burundi, a spokesman said Monday, but the insurgents claimed the dead were civilians.  The Hutus, were killed in Sunday fighting along the border between the provinces of Gitega and Mwaro, army spokesman Serge Nizigama said.  Gelase Ndabirabe, a spokesman for the rebel Forces for the Defense of Democracy, or FDD, said the victims were civilian men and boys rounded up by the army.  It was impossible to verify either claim."
Comments: This event includes an accusation on the part of the FDD that the army did not in fact kill rebels in this attack, but rounded up civilian Hutu males and massacred them.  The news article does not verify either side of the story, and the codes here indicate the rebel accusation, noting the contestation on behalf of the Burundian army.

Description: A Liberian human rights group has accused forces loyal to former president Charles Taylor of killing hundreds of civilians in a 2002 massacre during the country's 14-year war. The Catholic and Justice Peace Commission, citing testimony from four survivors, said in a statement women, children and elderly people, had been killed in the attack. In a statement published late on Thursday, the commission said the massacre took place in Tubmanburg, some 60 km (38 miles) north of the capital Monrovia on July 18, 2002. "The militias assembled hundreds of civilians and placed them under 'maximum security' surveillance before taking them to the bridge where they were allegedly slaughtered," it said. The statement said the exact number of people killed was not clear. It gave no explanation for the massacre, but said the militias had told the victims their commanders would give them some rice. A former top security official, named by the commission as a commander of the militias allegedly involved in the massacre, denied the accusations.
Comments: The perpetrators were supporters of Charles Taylor, the ruler of Liberia at the time of the incident.  The reason the villagers were killed is not clear so I coded the victims as unclear/other/random.  These allegations seem pretty reliable, although no firm number is given for the death count, the massacre fits with Taylor's history of human rights violations and atrocities.  One militia leader implicated in the attack denied the allegations, but no other voices of dissent are mentioned.  Among the human rights violations in this incident, mass detention is described, as "the militias assembled hundreds of civilians and placed them under maximum security surveillance" before they were killed.

Description: Soldiers loyal to former Liberian President Charles Taylor massacred 369 civilians last year in three southeastern villages, accusing them of supporting rebels in the area, the country's human rights commission said Saturday. The killings in April 2003 were allegedly ordered by the former commander in the region, William Sumo, the report said. Sumo's whereabouts are not known, but he is believed to be in Liberia. Defense Minister Daniel Chea, who held the same post under Taylor, described the report as "hard to believe." Quoting witnesses and survivors, the commission said the massacres took place after villagers and local chiefs expressed opposition to a 27-vehicle convoy that was carrying weapons and Liberian government soldiers to neighboring Ivory Coast to support a rebel faction in that country's civil war. Dempster said that after the convoy entered Ivory Coast, Sumo returned to the three villages and "accused them of supporting rebels that were attacking the (former) government of Liberia. This lead to mass arrests ... followed by executions." "Fifty-three people were executed in Yubor, 100 were executed in River Gbeh, and the rest, 216, were executed in Tuobo Gbaweleken," the report said.
Secondary.Source: Independent National Commission on Human Rights
Comments: AP presents this report from Liberia's human right's commission as established fact, the only voice of dissent is a defense minister who also worked under Taylor, who describes the report as "hard to believe," yet never actually contests the occurrence of the event.  The victims were explicitly described as civilians, targeted by soldiers for opposing the movement of a convoy through their region.

Description: In the narrow muddy lanes of the camp, dotted with straw huts, residents are still traumatised by the recent upsurge in fighting between Liberian rebels who besieged the capital city of Monrovia and government forces. 11 people have been killed and another 24 injured.
Comments: This is not a case of collateral damage; government troops on their way to Monrovia began shooting refugees in a camp and raping women and girls as young as five.

Description: What began as a military uprising to oust President Gbagbo soon became an ethnic conflict with reports of foreigners and Muslims being targeted in the capitol city of Abidjan by gangs armed with machetes.  The insurgency began the morning of 19 Sept. when rebels launched coordinated attacks on military installations, government sites, and Cabinet minister's houses throughout CIV.  A total of 270 were killed and 300 injured, but no breakdown on the casualties was available.
Comments: No breakdown of the casualty count was available so many, if not most of the deaths could be armed combatants or collateral damage.  However, because the article mentioned the targeting of foreigners and Muslims, I felt that it could be considered code worthy.

Description: Residents accused government troops of burning down homes and shooting civilians in attacks that targeted Muslims and migrants from Burkina Faso.  The military has staunchly denied involvement and claims that the attackers were rebels dressed as troops with the aim of tarnishing the fine reputation of the Ivory Coast military.  The head of the Islamic Council received reports that 56 Muslims had been shot dead and buried, while 19 other bodies were still lying in the streets.
Comments: The perpetrators in this incident remains in contestation.

Description: Ivory Coast rebels accused government troops of bombarding the western village of Pelezi with helicopters the night of 27 Nov., killing about 12 people, and wounding an equal number.  The Ivorian army confirmed that helicopters had indeed attacked the rebel territory, and French troops in the area were unable to confirm the allegations.
Comments: Information about the event is sparse. It is unclear whether civilians were the intended target of this attack, but the quotes from the army sources point towards the conclusion that the rebels holding the town were the target of said attack.

Description: Ivory Coast's army admitted on Wednesday that scores of people in a mass grave in the west of the country were killed by government troops, but said they were rebels who died in fighting rather than civilians. The rebel Patriotic Movement of Ivory Coast (MPCI) has said the grave in Monoko-Zohi, 70 km (45 miles) northwest of the loyalist-held cocoa town of Daloa, contained the bodies of 120 civilians - mostly foreign immigrants - killed by Ivorian troops after a raid in the rebel-held area. Foreign media have quoted residents of the village as backing the rebels' version. Government officials initially said loyalist troops had not been to Monoko-Zohi, near an area where a helicopter bombarded rebel positions on November 27 after President Laurent Gbagbo's forces accused them of breaking a ceasefire.
Comments: The facts are in dispute, but the rebel's version is lent credibility by the eyewitness accounts of the villagers.

Description: A spokesman for the Red Cross said that at least 150 people have died in the western town of Man, which was seized by rebels on 28 Nov. before being reclaimed by loyalist forces.  Two of the victims were reportedly executed by rebels for being suspected thieves.  According to one eyewitness, the loyalists just fired on civilians if they tried to run.
Comments: From the facts presented in the article, it seems that both the rebels and government loyalists can be held culpable for the more than 150 deaths.  Although firearms were the only weapons mentioned, it is possible and highly likely that other forms of violence were employed.

Description: France will demand an explanation from the authorities in Ivory Coast as to why a government military helicopter attacked a rebel-held village, killing 12 civilians and wounding several others, the foreign ministry said Thursday. Twelve civilians died when Ivorian troops loyal to President Laurent Gbagbo, fighting a rebellion that is into its fourth month, bombarded Menakro, a fishing village about 100 kilometres (60 miles) north of the inland capital of Yamoussoukro on Tuesday. At least one Russian-made MI-24 helicopter was used in the attack.  Ivory Coast army spokesman, Lieutenant-Colonel Jules Yao Yao, said the dead were insurgents and not civilians.
Comments: The motive for this attack is unclear, the government has not provided an explanation for the incident, although they did claim that they were responding to an earlier attack.  It is unclear whether the civilians were the direct target of the action and an army spokesman disputes the fact that the victims were civilians.  The number of injured is also unclear, the text mentions that several were injured.

Description: Ivory Coast helicopter gunships on Thursday strafed a rebel-held town in the west of the country and killed 15 civilians, insurgents said in the west African state. Felix Doh, head of the Ivorian Popular Movement of the Far West (MPIGO) rebel group based in the west of the country, told AFP that two government helicopter gunships fired on the town of Grabo. Ivorian army spokesman Lieutenant-Colonel Jules Yao Yao confirmed that government troops "were engaged in operations in the Grabo region," but did not confirm the firing. However, both French and Ivorian military sources said government forces had launched a military operation against rebels who were headed from Grabo to Tabou, a major port near the western border with Liberia, in which helicopters were used.
Comments: International news sources could not confirm this attack, and the Ivory Coast's military has denied killing the civilians.  However, the army did admit to being engaged in operations in the area against rebels, and that is why I coded this event as collateral damage.  Every indication points to the conclusion that the villagers were not intentionally targeted.

Description: Government helicopter gunships attacked a rebel-held Ivory Coast town, killing 20 civilians and injuring many others, a rebel leader said Sunday. Sgt. Felix Doh, leader of a rebel faction in western Ivory Coast, said his forces were attacked in Bin-Houye, a border town 320 miles northwest of the commercial capital, Abidjan. Ivory Coast government officials confirmed fighting took place in the town, but said rebels attacked loyalist forces first. The claim of civilian casualties could not immediately be verified.
Comments: The civilian deaths could not be verified and the details of the incident are in dispute.  Rebels claim that helicopters attacked and killed 20 civilians, while government forces claim that they were simply responding to an attack, which would make the unverified victims collateral damage.

Description: Weary and frightened villagers straggling in from the bush in western Ivory Coast tell of dozens of killings and wanton abuses after a surge of fighting that has soured hopes of peace. The involvement of warring Liberian tribes, inured to atrocities by years of bloodshed at home, has made an armed rebellion in this corner of the West African country even more savage and tangled. It is hard to get a precise toll for recent deaths from the accounts of those limping into the French-protected town of Duekoue - two women shot by the road here, five people killed there, another nine at a cocoa farmer's camp in the bush. "They killed 20 people last Wednesday. They just came and killed them. Women, old people, they killed them," planter Cesar Zrho, from a village north of Duekoue, said on Sunday.
Comments: This is a broadly worded report with few specifics. The alleged perpetrators include Liberian tribes, CIV rebels and CIV military.  Whether or not the victims are simply caught in the cross-fire of a civil war is not for certain, but the eye-witness accounts imply that civilians were often the targets.

Description: Government and rebel forces battled in Ivory Coast's western borderlands on Monday, days after the insurgents' first participation in a unity government meant to end the west African nation's civil war. Some 60 civilians died in recent days when government helicopter gunships attacked the insurgent-held town of Bin-Houye, near Ivory Coast's border with war-riven Liberia, rebel leader Felix Doh said by satellite telephone. Government spokesman N'Goran Aka said no civilians had died in the fighting, which Aka said continued Monday after rebels advanced Saturday against loyalist positions. "They attacked us, and we reacted with the arms at our disposition," said Aka, who said an unspecified number of government troops had suffered light injuries. Rebels "are all dressed in civilian clothes ... So when their soldiers are killed, they claim we killed civilians. It's not true. (Any dead) were combatants." Neither account could be independently verified.
Comments: Hefty allegations from both sides; it is impossible to discern who gives a truthful account.  That is why this event is coded as a rumor/allegation.

Description: Ivory Coast rebels accused the army of killing 15 civilians in a helicopter raid on a rebel base on Tuesday, a day after international peace monitors urged the grounding of the gunships. An army spokesman said he knew nothing of any strike on Danane, but he accused the rebels of attacking loyalist positions nearby and said the forces would use all means at their disposal to defend themselves. "We are still counting the casualties but there are 15 dead. They are civilians," said Bamba. He did not say if rebel fighters were also killed. If proved true, the attack would certainly deal another blow to a French-brokered peace agreement for the world's top cocoa producer - which brought rebel ministers into a power-sharing government last week after repeated false starts. There was no independent confirmation from the isolated region, where the conflict has been exacerbated by links to Liberia's civil war. Liberians, hardened by years of killing, rape and pillage, fight on both sides.
Comments: The rebels have alleged that this attack took place, but the CIV army has vehemently denied any knowledge of fighting in the area.  It is unclear whether Liberian mercenaries were involved, or if the alleged attack was provoked and civilian casualties could be considered collateral damage.

Description: Ivory Coast rebels said on Tuesday that government combat helicopters were continuing to attack western rebel-controlled areas, killing nine people, despite a promise by President Laurent Gbagbo to ground the aircraft following a peace accord. The Ivory Coast Patriotic Movement (MPCI), the country's largest rebel movement, said in a statement government helicopter gunships had killed six people on Tuesday and three on Monday in the towns of Zouan-Hounien, Danane and Mahapleu, all close to Ivory Coast's border with Liberia. The spokesman for Ivory Coast's Chief of Staff, Lieutenant Colonel N'Goran Aka, rejected the rebel accusations and told AFP the combat helicopters had not taken off on either Monday or Tuesday. But a French military official told AFP on Monday he had seen government helicopters flying to the west, and an informed source, who declined to be identified, said on Tuesday army gunships were seen in the west.
Comments: This event has been denied by the alleged perpetrators; therefore, the incident was coded as a rumour/allegation.

Description: West African peacekeepers headed to rebel-held territory in western Ivory Coast on Friday to investigate reports of fighting and claims that government helicopters bombarded a market, killing and wounding civilians. Rebel claims that Mi-24 helicopters have repeatedly bombed their positions this week have cast a shadow over the creation of a power-sharing government, including rebel ministers, meant to end a seven-month civil war in the former French colony. A spokesman for the regional peacekeeping force said a team was in the western town of Vavoua, where rebels say 10 civilians and one insurgent were killed in a helicopter raid on Wednesday. Aid workers said they knew of at least one death there.
Comments: This event is an allegation that has not been confirmed by an independent agency.  One death was confirmed by an aid worker, but rebels claim that 10 civilians fell victim to the government attack.

Description: At least 10 Malians, including a Muslim cleric, have been killed in violence in Ivory Coast's main city Abidjan since the Ivorian army quashed an anti-government demonstration there last week, an official said Thursday.
Comments: Many different numbers were reported in this event.  All agree that Malians were targeted and killed after the demonstrations as well as during.  Officials in Mali claim at least 10, the press say 7, but Malians in Ivory Coast say that the toll could exceed

Description: An Agence France Press report told "Ivory Coast's peace process was in shambles Thursday as opposition parties and former rebels quit the unity regime in protest at the killing of up to 30 people by security forces who quashed a demonstration against President Laurent Gbagbo."
Comments: Articles later noted a significant difference between the government's and the opposition's count of the deaths.  Agence France Presse (AFPR000020040327e03r000xz) wrote that "The streets of Abidjan returned to life Saturday after two days of bloody clashes between demonstrators and police that the opposition says killed about 160 people and the police insists killed 25, including two of their own. "There are about 160 dead," said Alphone Djedje Mady, secretary general of the Ivory Coast Democratic Party. "The dead were counted at the morgue."" Then, in a later report the official death toll was raised to 37 (AFPR000020040328e03s000pz).  Yet, accordingly, the oppositions' assessment was raised to 300 AFPR000020040328e03s000un). One other report told that 'between 350 and 500 people were killed' (AFPR000020040328e03s000y0).

Description: Dozens of Malians have been summarily executed in a security forces crackdown in neighboring Ivory Coast, a political group here charged late Monday. "They are killing Malians and other foreigners by the dozens" in the wake of the quashing of a banned anti-government protest in Abidjan last week, an official of African Solidarity for Democracy and Independence (SADI), told AFP in the Malian capital Bamako. He said many Malians were killed Friday at a mosque in Abobo, a working-class district of Abidjan, Ivory Coast's main city, adding that many more had gone missing. SADI, in a statement released in Bamako, condemned "killings and persecutions of Malians" and charged that police stations in Abidjan had become "centers for summary executions."
Comments: This is merely an allegation by the SADI political group in Mali and has not yet been confirmed or denied.  No specifics are given.

Description: Ivorian authorities said a total of 57 civilians were killed and more than 2,200 injured between November 6 and 10, including an unconfirmed number by French troops -- but there is no specific toll for the Hotel Ivoire protest. The death toll was provisional, not definitive, the defence ministry source added. In every case, the French soldiers were acting in legitimate self-defence or to defend themselves and others, the source said.

"Sudanese rebels accused pro-government militias Monday of killing some 300 civilians in Kuttum, the second largest town in North Darfur state.  'We call on international organisations to investigate what happened in Kuttum,' Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) Secretary General Mani Arkoi Minawi told AFP here by telephone.  Minawi charged that some 350 pro-government militiamen entered Kuttum on August 5 after the SLM pulled out of the town....  'They burnt and destroyed houses and shops,' added the rebel chief, who said he was speaking from an area near Kuttum."
Comments: The scorched earth tactics involved with this incident include the burning of homes and businesses in the town of Kuttum.  The weapons used in this lead were at least primitive weapons (fire), but there were likely firearms and possibly heavy weapons used as well, even though there is no mention of these in the article.

Description: "Sudanese rebels accused government forces Tuesday of having killed 46 civilians and destroyed 500 villages in North Darfur state, in the west of the country.  'Antonov planes bombarded on Sunday and Monday the city of Kornoy, at the extreme west of North Darfur, killing 46 people, including children, women and elderly,' said Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) Secretary General Mani Arkoi Minawi.
Comments: Heavy weapons were coded because Antonov planes bombarded the targets during this raid.  Scorched earth tactics were coded here because as a result of these bombings, over 500 villages were destroyed.

Description: "The rebel movement in western Sudan charged Sunday that pro-government militias had killed 81 civilians in the past two days as well having 'systematically violated' an eight-day truce.  In a telephone call to AFP in Cairo, Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) secretary general Mani Arkoi Minawi accused the Sudanese government of having 'systematically and daily violated the truce' since it took effect September 6.  Seventy-five civilians were killed Friday when militiamen allied to the government launched an attack against residents of Khashaba, in the north of Kuttum province, Minawi said.  Sixteen shepherds were killed Saturday when pro-government militiamen launched another attack in the area of Abu Leiha, he added."
Comments: This campaign is actually the combination of two related incidents that were reported simultaneously.

Description: "Sudanese state forces and pro-government militia fighters killed more than 60 people on Saturday in two attacks in the west of the country, a rebel leader said on Sunday.  The Sudanese government and the western-based rebel group, the Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A), agreed a ceasefire in September, and extended it last week, to end fighting that began in February in the arid and poor western Darfur region.  'The government carried out two attacks against civilian areas yesterday (Saturday) in the Darfur region which killed dozens of people and made many thousands homeless,' Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur, an SLM/A leader, told Reuters."
Comments: The Sudanese forces and the pro-government militia coordinated this attack on villages in the Darfur region.

Description: "At least 10 civilians were killed Friday during a bombing raid by Sudanese government forces on villages and rebel positions in the country's troubled western Darfur region, a rebel official said.  The official from the Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) accused the government of committing with the bombing attacks a 'flagrant violation of the ceasefire' that has been in place since September 3."
Comments: The heavy weapons used in this event were bombs used in a air raid over a handful of villages in the Darfur region.  The reuters report upped the death count to about 30 (but this report extended the campaign to include a ground raid).

Description: "Rebels from the west of Sudan said on Friday government air raids had killed 14 people in the poor arid region, in what they said the latest breach of a ceasefire agreement signed by both sides.  The rebel Sudan Liberation Army/Movement (SLA/M) emerged as a fighting force in the western Darfur region in February, accusing the Khartoum government of marginalising the area."
Comments: This campaign is a combination of two incidents, one bombing raid killed 6 people in north Darfur, and 8 people were killed in a raid in west Darfur.  In a later Reuters report the death toll was upped to 40 and 60 injured (AFP updated their report 47 dead and 37 injured).

Description: "A western Sudanese rebel group said on Thursday the Khartoum government had killed 25 civilians after launching an air raid in the poor Darfur region of Africa's largest country.  The Justice and Equality Movement (JEM), one of two main rebel groups that started a revolt in Darfur in February and accuse Khartoum of marginalising the area, said a plane bombed civilians for 15 minutes on Wednesday morning."

"A Sudanese politician said on Monday that Arab militias had killed 19 people and burned seven villages at the weekend in the western Darfur region.  Jafar Ismail also urged the government to stop an escalating conflict in Darfur, where two main rebel groups launched a revolt in February saying the Khartoum government marginalised the impoverished area.  Rebels accuse government forces of air raids and other attacks and say Khartoum has armed Arab militias to attack African tribes in the region, where tensions over scarce resources are rife."
Comments: the scorched earth tactics coded here are the burning of seven villages in Darfur.

Description: "Rebels in western Sudan on Saturday accused government forces of massacring civilians in a village in the remote Darfur region and called for urgent help for thousands of people uprooted by fighting.  The Sudan Liberation Movement/Army (SLM/A) said 200 civilians including children and elderly people were killed on Friday in an attack on Sorra village."
Comments: This is an unsubstantiated accusation of atrocity.  The Reuters report does not verify the accusation.  There is no identification of weapons used in this alleged atrocity.  The victims identified in the accusation are said to be civilians, so their noncombatant status is asserted and was not reportedly contested.  The seizures coded here include the fact that the government forces allegedly emptied towns of their inhabitants, who fled the violence.

Description: "Sudanese government planes have bombed the town of Tine in the western Darfur region, a diplomat in Chad said Tuesday.  'The bombardment comes after an ultimatum made a few days ago by the Sudanese authorities, demanding that the town of Tine be evacuated, failing which they would raze the town,' the diplomat said....  The rebel Movement for Justice and Equality (MJE), which controls Tine, confirmed in a statement that the Khartoum government had launched a bombing raid on the town and other areas in Darfur on Monday, killing 45 people, 'most of them children, women and the elderly....'  Personnel at the Sudanese embassy in Chad refused to confirm or deny the alleged bombing raids.  'If there were bombings, they would only target rebel sites and positions,' the embassy said, adding that 'no civilians live in Tine, only rebels.'"
Comments: The bombings here reported are not confirmed by the Sudanese government, and furthermore, Khartoum refuses to admit the killing of any civilians.  The Sudanese embassy said that "if there were bombings, they would only target rebel sites and positions no civilians live in Tine, only rebels."  Since the article does not indicate that only rebels live in Tine, the noncombatant status of the victims is coded as "contested" even though the article contains no explicit assertion that the residents were noncombatants. The vicitm identity in this case is tough to code.  On one hand, they could have been random residents of the town, but on the other hand, they probably were politically targeted because of the circumstances surrounding the bombing.  Prior to the alleged bombings, the government warned the residents of the region to evacuate.  This indicates that the government prepared to bomb for a specific reason, namely to kill rebels.
