Presumably there would be a political gain in doing so, and even if civilians did die in the meantime, there would have been political gain (e.g. the government is "tough on rebels.")  Therefore, the vicitms are coded as both "random/unclear/other" and "political."  Also, for these reasons, I have chosen to code any noncombatant deaths as "collateral damage."  The intent is coded as "intent apparent but not asserted" over "killing deliberate, but victims not intentionally targeted" because it is obvious that the possibility of "collateral" deaths existed in this instance.  Later Reuters and AFP reports confirm that the bombing did occur.

Description: "Sudanese forces and pro-government militia have burned several villages and killed more than 175 civilians in west Sudan in recent attacks during an ongoing government offensive, a rebel official said on Sunday.  Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur, chairman of the rebel Sudan Liberation Army (SLA),... said more than 100 civilians were also killed on Saturday when five villages were torched in the Jebel Moon area, northeast of Geneina.
Secondary.Source: SLA chairman Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur
Comments: This event was reported in the same lead as the linked event.  They happened on the same day, but were reported separately and with separate death counts.  The death estimate is approximate therefore it is coded as a range.  The "Scorched Earth" tactic employed in these killings is the reported burning of the victim's homes.  In the same vein, the weapon used is "primitive" because the only means reported is fire.

Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur, chairman of the rebel Sudan Liberation Army (SLA),... told Reuters four villages were burned and more than 75 civilians killed in government-led attacks on Saturday in the area of west Jebel Marra, about 200 km (125 miles) east of Geneina."
Secondary.Source: SLA chairman Abdel Wahed Mohamed Ahmed al-Nur
Comments: This event was reported in the same lead as the linked event.  They happened on the same day, but were reported separately and with separate death counts.  The death estimate is approximate therefore it is coded as a range.  The "Scorched Earth" tactic employed in these killings is the reported burning of the victim's homes.  In the same vein, the weapon used is "primitive" because the only means reported is fire.

Description: "Amnesty International said Wednesday it had received reports of 'horrifying attacks' against civilians in western Sudan by government forces fighting a yearlong rebellion.  The London-based human rights group said it had information that government-backed militias attacked five villages in southern Darfur on Feb. 11, killing between 68 and 80 civilians.  Between Feb. 10 and Feb. 12, government aircraft also bombed 11 towns and villages in west Darfur, while pro-government militia killed people fleeing their homes, including an Islamic preacher, Amnesty said in a statement.  Government soldiers also allegedly abducted 30 girls in an attack in west Darfur last week, Amnesty said.
Comments: The perpetrators in this case are "government warplanes" and "government-backed militias" that carried out air and ground raids on these "civilians" in western Sudan over three days.  The weapons included bombs dropped from warplanes and firearms on the ground.  The range of deaths reported by both AFP and Amnesty was 68-80.  The alleged kidnapping of 30 girls by government forces "last week" is included in this code because it seems to be related to this campaign although no date was given.

Description: "Sudan's army bombed a town in the western Darfur region, killing six civilians and injuring 25, eyewitnesses said on Saturday, weeks after the government said major military operations were over in the area.  A resident of Sherya town, about 70 kilometres east of the Southern Darfur state capital Nyala, said that Antonov planes began bombarding the town on Friday evening and Arab militias known as 'Janjaweed' attacked at the same time."
Comments: This seems to be a coordinated attack by the Sudanese army and the "Janjaweed" or an Arab militia group.  At the same time, Sudanese planes bombed the Darfur town, and the militia stormed the town, looting and firing guns in the air.  The Janjaweed stole cattle and burned houses (scorched earth tactics).  Both of the perpetrators are listed, even though the air raid is considered the only weapon that actually killed any victims.

Description: Militias backing the Khartoum government have violated a ceasefire in Sudan's western Darfur region, killing 32 civilians, a rebel group charged Thursday.  Colonel Abdallah Abdel Karim, military spokesman of the Justice and Equality Movement (MJE), said Janjaweed militiamen and government troops had torched villages northwest of the Darfur state capital Geneina near the border with Chad on Wednesday.  Karim ... added that the 32 people allegedly killed in the raids were 'mostly women, elderly and children.'  The claim could not be independently confirmed."
Comments: While primitive weapons (fire) are the only form of weapons reported in this article, that does not preclude the use of other weapons, specifically firearms, in this case.  This event is also coded as a case in which "scorched earth tactics" were used because the perpetrators reportedly "torched" a number of villages northwest of the Darfur state capital Geneina.  This event is a subset of a larger campaign that spans the first months of 2004 and into 2003.  All the reports in this campaign are coded with their own campaign identifier code and also linked as BNL 0317 02.

Description: "Sudanese government forces killed six civilians and wounded 10 others in aerial bombardments in the latest ceasefire violation in west Sudan, a rebel spokesman said on Tuesday.  The government was not immediately available for comment, but Sudanese military sources said last week they were still pursuing rebels in an area near the latest reported attack despite a truce signed in April between the two sides.  'he government carried out aerial bombardment using Antonov planes and helicopters on the Korma area in Northern Darfur state targeting our soldiers resulting in the death of six civilians and the injury of 10,' Mohammed Mursal, spokesman for the Sudanese Liberation Army (SLA), told Reuters."
Comments: The weapons used in this killing were Antonov planes and helicopters that dropped bombs over the region.  The Sudanese forces were likely targeting rebels in the area, and ended up killing civilians in the process.  While these civilian casualties were probably expected, it is assumed here that the killings were a case of collateral damage.

Description: "Forty-five Sudanese were killed in a recent attack on a village by pro-government militiamen in Darfur, the main rebel group in the troubled western region said Sunday.  The Arab militia unknown as the Janjaweed, which has been accused of atrocities, attacked Abquarajel village Thursday, a senior Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) member, Mohamed Mersal, told AFP by telephone here.  Another 10 people were wounded in the attack on the village located 15 kilometres (almost 10 miles) south of Nyala, the capital of Southern Darfur state, he said."
Comments: There was no indication from the lead about the weapons used in these killings, but the Janjaweed are known to use firearms in their killings in Darfur.  Reuters reported 56 casualties and AFP cited only 45, but I chose to code the Reuters number.  The later Reuters report also claimed that the perpetrators were using firearms in the raid.  In the AP report the governor of South Darfur Province claimed that a band of rebels were responsible for the killings, implicitly denying the accusation that the government had a role in the deaths.

Description: "Villagers in west Sudan said Sudanese aircraft bombed their village on Friday and killed at least 11 people, but a local airport official denied there had been any attack.  The witnesses told Reuters by mobile and satellite telephone from the area that an Antonov plane and helicopters bombed the village of Tabit, about 40 km (25 miles) southwest of al-Fashir, the capital of Northern Darfur state. A rebel official also reported an aerial attack....  'There has been no aerial bombardment. These people are lying. We are going to hear a lot of these kinds of lies in the future,' the official said by telephone."
Comments: An Antonov plane and helicopters are the alleged means that were used to deliver bombs on the town.  The Sudanese military flatly denies that the event occurred, calling the witnesses "liars."  There were a range of deaths reported ("killed at least 11 people").  A rebel group cited 20 dead and 17 wounded in a separate report.

Description: Twenty-four people have been killed in a two-day assault by government forces on a village in Sudan's war-ravaged western Darfur region, the rebel Justice and Equality Movement (MJE) said on Tuesday. Khartoum's forces launched an air strike on the village of Adjidji, south of Geneina in West Darfur, in breach of a ceasefire agreement, MJE spokesman Colonel Abdallah Abdel Kerim told AFP by satellite telephone. "The Janjaweed (pro-government Arab militias) and the army then attacked the village and killed 24 people," all civilians," he said. The attack reportedly took place on Monday and Tuesday. Fighting between government forces and two rebel groups in Darfur has left some 10,000 people dead since February 2003 and sparked what the United Nations has described as the world's worst humanitarian crisis.
Secondary.Source: The rebel Justice and Equality Movement
Comments: Because heavy weapons were used in the initial strike, this was coded as such.  The article made mention of the follow-up attack by the army and militia the next day, but fails to mention what weapons were used in the second phase.

Description: "The main rebel group in Sudan on Monday claimed that 204 civilians have been killed in the south of the country over the last few days in renewed fighting with government forces and Khartoum-backed militias.  ' can confirm that there has been fighting around Akobo (on the border with Ethiopia). Our sources on the ground indicate that 204 civilians were killed,' Sudan People's Liberation Army's (SPLA) spokesman George Garang told AFP by phone.  There was no independent confirmation of the death toll...."
Comments: There are no reported dates for this event, because the only time identification given in the article was that there was reported fighting "over a few days."  the day fields have been left blank, but it is reasonable to assume that the fighting both began and ended in the month of may.  The weapons used in this fighting were not identified.

Description: Rebel accusations that new government air raids killed 26 civilians in Sudan's troubled Darfur region cast a pall over peace talks in Nigeria, where African Union mediators struggled Wednesday to broker an end to fighting that has killed tens of thousands of people. A Sudan army official denied the rebel report. Lt. Gen. Mohammed Ismail, deputy chief of staff of the Sudanese army, said there had been no new violence in Darfur, which the United Nations has said is site of the world's worst humanitarian crisis. A spokesman for the rebel Sudan Liberation Army, Mahgoup Hussain, said the bombings occurred Tuesday and Wednesday in Allaiat, a town in eastern Darfur. Hussain, who said a pregnant woman was among the 26 victims, spoke at the end of a third day of peace talks that so far have failed to yield any agreement. The conflict has displaced 1.5 million people since it started in February 2003.

A rebel group Friday accused the Sudanese military and allied militias of carrying out a massacre of dozens of civilians in the strife-torn Darfur region of western Sudan this week. A Sudan Liberation Army (SLA) spokesman told AFP that government forces had killed up to 100 civilians around Adoua, 45 kilometers (30 miles) north of Nyala, the capital of South Darfur state, between November 29 and December 2. The fighting broke out when government forces, backed by armored carriers and an Antonov aircraft attacked SLA-controlled Adoua, forcing out the 30 SLA fighters defending the town, according to Ali. "Nearly 600 Arab Janjaweed militias were also involved in the assault," the spokesman added. "Some of our fighters died in the battle and others withdrew from the town." He said that civilians caught up in the fighting were unable to flee and many of them were killed by the Janjaweed, the government proxy militias blamed for many atrocities in the region. There was no independent confirmation of the charges and no immediate comment from the Khartoum government. Local authorities refused to allow an AU helicopter to land in the town to investigate, as the military had yet to wipe out the evidence, according to the SLA spokesman.

A rebel group in Sudan's troubled Darfur region accused pro-government Arab Janjaweed militias and the police Wednesday of attacking a village in South Darfur and killing 17 civilians.  "They then mutilated the bodies and buried them in a mass grave," the Sudan Liberation Movement charged in a statement received by AFP in Cairo and which claimed the attack took place Monday at Tawal Balal. It added that the attackers also raped four women, including a 17-year-old girl.

Sudan said on Sunday it was probing a U.N. report that its air force bombed a town in Darfur and promised to punish the troops if it were true. A United Nations spokesman said on Friday that the Sudanese air force bombed the town of Shangil Tobaya, near el-Fasher, capital of North Darfur, last week killing or wounding 100 people and forcing thousands to flee. "We have formed an investigation committee to find out what happened and if there was a bombing," Sudanese Interior Minister Abdel Rahim Mohamed Hussein told Reuters on a visit to Dubai. "Armies all over the world have committed mistakes and it is possible that an isolated bombing took place. If this is so, we will punish the offenders."

Description: Agence France Presse reported "At least 14 people have been killed in clashes between demonstrators from a local tribe and security forces in Port Sudan, on the Red Sea, the local governor said Saturday.  Provincial governor Major General Hatim al-Wasilah al-Sammani told AFP that 14 people were killed and 16 others wounded in the clashes. "

Sudanese troops and helicopters killed seven civilians and wounded about 10 in attacks on villages in the western Darfur region, the rebel commander of the area told Reuters on Monday.  A Sudanese official who did not want to give his name said the attacks were aimed at rebel bases not civilians and the only casualties were rebel fighters.  The attacks took place at two separate sites along the road between Nyala and al-Fasher on Sunday, rebel commanders said.  "They (Sudanese forces) killed three civilians in Abu Hamra and four in Sheng al-Tobei," said Adam Yacoub, the rebel Sudan Liberation Movement (SLM) commander of the area. "About 10 people were wounded in total," he added.  The Sudanese official, who cast doubt on the details given by the rebels, said the attack came as a response to an assault on an unarmed government convoy on Saturday in the same area.  "The armed forces attacked two rebel camps after the attack on our unarmed convoy ... All those who died in the attacks were rebels," the official said.
Secondary.Source: Adam Yacoub, rebel SLM commander of the area

Description: Rebels and Sudanese forces have clashed in North Darfur with artillery fire killing 5 civilians, the Sudanese government said Monday. The African Union, which is monitoring a shaky cease-fire deal between rebels and the government in the crisis-wracked Darfur region, said rebels attacked an army outpost early Sunday, which was followed by "heavy bombardment" apparently from Sudanese soldiers. The fighting took place southeast of the town of Kutum before Sudanese soldiers chased the rebel fighters from the Sudan Liberation Army into the nearby villages of Kenin and Nadi, the AU said in a statement. But the Sudanese government accused "a group of armed movements in Darfur (of launching) waves of indiscriminate shelling" on Kutum, which resulted in "human and material damage" on Sunday and Saturday. "The outcome was the death and injury of a group of children, women and elderly citizens," said a statement issued by a Sudanese government delegation at Darfur peace talks in the Nigerian capital, Abuja. Another five civilians were injured.

A rebel group on Saturday accused Sudanese government troops and their militia allies of killing 27 people and stealing livestock in attacks on villages in the Darfur region of western Sudan.  The attacks, which took place on Friday according to the rebel group, came as diplomatic efforts intensified at the African Union (AU) and the United Nations to speed up peace talks and solve a row over a proposed U.N. presence in Darfur.  "These villages have been completely destroyed. They killed 27 people, 17 are injured and six are missing including children," he said, adding that he had obtained this information by telephone from JEM members in the area.  "They took 150 heads of cattle and 300 sheep," Tugod said.  government army spokesman in Khartoum said the army and popular defence forces, the official militia, had not moved into the area.

Description: Clashes between the Sudanese army and opposition forces in the country's east saw eight people killed, the army said in a statement Wednesday. The incident saw forces loyal to the Justice and Equality Movement, from Darfur, western Sudan, team up with the Beja Congress, from the east, to attack army positions in eastern Sudan, according to an army statement run by SUNA, the official news agency. Brigadier Osman Mohamed Al Aghbash said six civilians and two people from the attacking groups died, said the statement in his name. The opposition forces "attacked army positions in Wagar and Tinay, simultaneously," destroyed a truck, burnt down a police station and knocked down telecommunications equipment, the statement said.

Rebels from the NRF, the coalition that has rejected the peace deal, said in a statement that janjaweed backed by the army killed dozens of people over the past few days -- including 15 in two separate raids on Sunday. The Sudanese military categorically denied it conducted or backed any raids.

Rebels from the NRF, the coalition that has rejected the peace deal, said in a statement that janjaweed backed by the army killed dozens of people over the past few days -- including eight on Monday in the South Darfur village of Angabo. The Sudanese military categorically denied it conducted or backed any raids.

A Sudanese rebel group has accused government troops and allied militias of attacking its positions in northern Darfur, killing more than 50 people. An army spokesman denied the claim.  Abdel Wahed al-Nur, head of one faction of the rebel Sudan Liberation Army (SLA), said the army, backed by janjaweed militia, attacked the Deir Mazza area on Wednesday.  "About three armed men of the movement were also killed in the attack. The innocent citizens included women and children," Nur said late on Wednesday, adding that the government used fighter planes.  A Sudanese army spokesman who declined to be named said on Thursday no operations had been conducted in that area in the past few days and the report was "100 percent incorrect".

The NRF said that about 500 janjaweed backed by regular Sudanese soldiers attacked the North Darfur town of Madu. The assailants "gathered some children in a grass hut and burnt them alive inside it. Parents who interfered were shot dead," the statement said. A U.N. official in the region said Sunday's violence occurred when the janjaweed came to Madu to recruit fighters and were poorly received by the ethnic African villagers. The official spoke on condition of anonymity because of the difficulties facing international workers in Darfur. The official said observers were investigating reports that four children and two adults were killed during the Madu raid but could not confirm that children were intentionally burned alive. The Sudanese military categorically denied it conducted or backed any raids.

A U.N. official confirmed Tuesday that a new Sudanese government air force bombing had killed eight members of a family in a North Darfur village. Jar al-Naby, a field commander for the rebel group that controls the zone, said government aircraft bombed the village of Hashaba on Monday, destroying one house. Two men, five children and their mother were killed, he said on the telephone.

Maoist rebels ambushed two separate army patrols in western Nepal near Madhuradanda village and Chisapani.  At least five civilians, including a 13-year-old boy, were killed in the crossfire along with many rebels and soldiers.

Description: A Nepalese soldier ended an argument with a group of villagers by spraying them with bullets, killing at least 11 people and injuring 19. The killings occurred in Nagarkot and drew a slew of protestors to the hospital where the injured were being treated. The Nepalese army identified the soldier who opened fire and said he was killed in the incident. It did not elaborate.  The army's human rights cell insists it was an "act of madness of just one soldier" but villagers were not appeased.  Other details of the attack were not provided.

Associated Press Newswires reported on April 26, 2006 from Nepal that: "soldiers opened fire Wednesday on a crowd of thousands of villagers angry about the death of a local woman at an army base in southwestern Nepal, killing six and wounding at least 11, officials said....Versions why the shooting occurred differed dramatically. Both the military and rights activists agree that thousands of angry civilians marched on the camp in the village of Belbari, angry about the woman's death there the night before. But while Bhupendra Poudel, the defense ministry spokesman, said the crowd tore down the camp's barbed wire, sought to snatch solders' guns and tried to storm the small base, Kunjan Aryal of the rights group INSEC-Nepal said the villagers were protesting peacefully. "They were not trying to storm in," he said. "They were simply protesting." Poudel also said the woman -- a suspected Maoist -- had been shot when she tried to slip into the base. Aryal, though, said the villagers believed the woman had been raped and killed by the soldiers. Poudel said 11 villagers had been injured, while Aryal put the total at 29.Aryal also believed the crowd had been emboldened by the country's political turmoil, when weeks of protests of hundreds of thousands of people forced King Gyanendra to return power to elected officials a few days ago. "Because of the recent political changes they appear to be bold enough to march up to the army camp and seek justice," said Aryal, adding an INSEC staff member was at the base at the time of the shooting." A related Reuters report noted that "The demonstration was not linked to weeks of pro-democracy protests" and placed the number of protesters at the camp at approximately 100. However, Agence France quoted a rights activist as saying "some 2,000 people had gathered at the base after rumours spread that the woman had been raped and killed by a soldier."
Primary.Source: Associated Press, Reuters News,  Agence France Presse
Secondary.Source: "Bhupendra Poudel, the defense ministry spokesman" "Kunjan Aryal of the rights group INSEC-Nepal"
Citation: Associated Press 04/26/2006 (APRS000020060426e24q000fh); Reuters 04/26/2006 (LBA0000020060426e24q001ho); Agence France Presse (AFPR000020060426e24q002yj)
Comments: The Reuters and Agence France reports did not include the quote by Kunan Ayal (asserting that villagers were protesting peacefully), the only quoted the defense ministry's statement (stating that the villagers were storming the base and the soldiers acted in "self-defence") while the Associated Press report noted this discrepancy.

Description: The Associated Press reported on 02/28/2004 that, according to local officials, "Pakistani forces opened fire on a minibus Saturday [02/28/2004] when it failed to stop at a roadblock in a tribal region where anti-terrorism operations have been ongoing, killing at least 11 people"; reportedly, "the bus was filled mostly with Afghan refugees on their way to the border"; according to a local resident, "a taxi driving near the minibus was also hit, and the driver killed"; reportedly, "he [the local resident] said as many as 12 people were killed, and seven more injured in the incident" (a later AP report indicated that 13 people had been killed); Reuters reported that "at least 10 people were killed when Pakistani troops opened fire on a van they mistakenly believed was carrying Islamic militants"; a separate AP report indicated that a Pakistani "army spokesman" claimed that "the killings... occurred only after paramilitary forces were fired on" by "someone in the bus"--reportedly, residents disputed the army's claim, saying they were "outraged by the shootings" and that "innocent people were killed in this operation... it was a civilian vehicle and the army is at fault"; reportedly, Pakistani President Musharraf, in a "message to the bereaved families... expressed his 'profound grief and sorrow over the incident'"
Primary.Source: Agence France Presse, Associated Press, Reuters
Comments: Event Reporting coded as Secondary, Not Contested since the AFP, AP, and Reuters reports cited local officials and local residents and since the AFP, AP, and Reuters reports seemed to present the occurrence of the event, as described by the local officials and residents, as a fact (here and throughout, when I have encountered reports in which only one secondary account of a given event is offered, I have interpreted the lack of an expression of doubt regarding the credibility of the secondary source's account as tantamount to representing the occurrence of the event, as described by the secondary source, as a fact); Intent coded as Noncombatants Not Intentionally Targeted and Collateral Damage coded as Collateral Damage since the wording in the reports suggested that the incident was a case of mistaken identity (reportedly, "Pakistani troops opened fire on a van they mistakenly believed was carrying Islamic militants"); Regrets coded as Perpetrator Regrets since, reportedly, Pakistani President Musharraf sent a message to the bereaved families to express his "profound grief and sorrow over the incident"

Description: Reuters reported on 03/20/2004 that, according to "a senior security official", "up to 13 civilians died in western Pakistan on Saturday [03/20/2004] when their vehicles were fired upon"; reportedly, "there were differing accounts and death tolls, with two officials saying a Pakistani army helicopter had been responsible for the attack in South Waziristan where troops have been battling al Qaeda and allied militants for days"; according to "a local security official", "12 people including women and children had been killed by an army helicopter hunting militants on Saturday afternoon... 'After the army received casualties the gunship helicopters were directed to hit the cars,' said the official"; however, "an army spokesman denied that civilians had been killed but said some people had been killed in an army attack early on Saturday when trying to escape through the army cordon... 'A number of people were killed there but they were those who were trying to escape... No innocent people have been killed'"

Description: The Associated Press reported on 09/08/2004 that "Pakistani troops opened fire at a bazaar in this tense tribal town [Wana] on Wednesday [09/08/2004], killing six tribesmen and wounding 11, moments after a land mine exploded near a nearby army convoy"; reportedly, "injured witnesses accused soldiers of spraying fire at innocent civilians in the wake of the blast in Wana, the main town in South Waziristan, a tribal region near the Afghan border where al-Qaida-linked militants are active"; according to a local resident, "moments after the blast, some soldiers started firing at the people who were present in the bazaar... we don't know who attacked the army, but they killed our innocent brothers without any reason"; reportedly, a Pakistani army spokesman said "six people 'died in a cross-fire' in Wednesday's clash, but said he didn't know yet if they were 'civilians or miscreants'"; a related AFP report indicated that "eight people were killed and 11 injured" in the incident; reportedly, "six people, all local tribesmen were killed on the spot and two more died in the hospital"; according to the AFP report, "[PAK] military officials said the civilians died in firing by 'miscreants'"

Comments: I have coded this event twice, as two linked records, since the secondary sources cited in the AP report disagreed on some of the details of the event and since the information provided could not be accommodated in a single record

Description: The Associated Press reported on 09/13/2004 that "Pakistan's army said it has killed 150 militants in a series of counterterrorism operations this year in South Waziristan, where fighting continued Monday [09/13/2004] with artillery barrages against suspected al-Qaida-linked fighters"; reportedly, "a local tribesman reported eight people had died in the most recent fighting, and intelligence sources confirmed at least one death, but an army spokesman said reports of civilian casualties in recent clashes were unfounded"; according to the local resident, "shells fired by [PAK] security forces hit three homes in Makin... [killing] eight people... including two women and two children aged 6 and 4"; reportedly, "[PAK] intelligence officials... confirmed that one man was killed when his home was hit in crossfire between militants and security forces in Makin... He [a PAK intelligence official] said there were other reports of civilian casualties, but these could not be confirmed because the area was off-limits"
Comments: Event Reporting coded as Rumor/Allegation since the AP report indicated only that the local resident "claimed" that eight civilians were killed

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 10/27/2004 that, according to "a [PAK] military spokesman", "fourteen tribal leaders trying to help Pakistani forces organise the surrender of Al-Qaeda-linked militants in a remote region near the Afghan border have been killed"; reportedly, "another six people were injured in the incident, Major General Shaukat Sultan told AFP, laying the blame for the deaths on a militant rocket attack"; according to the PAK military spokesman, "'the casualties were caused by miscreants"; reportedly, however, "another tribal elder who said he was present during the tragedy, Azizullah Mahsud, claimed the military was responsible, and local press reports raised the prospect of a 'friendly fire' mistake"; reportedly, "the incident occurred Tuesday [10/26/2004] in the tribal tow of Sheikh Ziarat near Spinkai Raghzai in the troubled South Waziristan region where Pakistani troops are engaged in a hunt for Al-Qaeda-militants and their local sympathisers"

Description: A gun battle between Pakistani soldiers and militants killed 18 people, including women and children, in a northwestern tribal region near the Afghan border, the military said Sunday. A military source, speaking on condition of anonymity for security reasons, said the dead included 15 women and children and two men. The source spoke to The Associated Press from the northwestern city of Peshawar.
Comments: The militants were not identified further.  And the government stated that the shootout only resulted in a few civilian deaths.

Description: Agence France Presse reported on 01/11/2006 that "Pakistani forces shot dead 12 suspected tribal militants in the country's unstable southwest Wednesday [01/11/2006] after a roadside bomb blast killed three soldiers, a government official said... the incidents near the Pirkoh gas field, about 400 kilometres (250 miles) southeast of Quetta, were the bloodiest for months to rock the increasingly volatile province of Baluchistan... the three paramilitary Frontier Corps soldiers died and three were wounded when their vehicle carrying food for the gas field was hit a remote controlled bomb, district coordination officer Abdul Samad Lasi told AFP... shortly afterwards dozens of armed insurgents attacked the gas field, which is near Dera Bugti, the stronghold of diehard anti-government tribal chieftain Nawab Akbar Bugti... 'The soldiers retaliated and killed 12 miscreants,' Lasi said, using the official Pakistani jargon for extremists... 'The miscreants wanted to occupy the gas field,' he added... the violence came as Pakistan celebrated of the Muslim festival of sacrifice, Eid Al-Adha"; reportedly, "However the Jamhoori Watan Party, a regional political group in Baluchistan with links to tribal leader Bugti, rejected the government's account of the incident... Party secretary general Agha Shahid Bugti denied that any tribesmen were killed in the clash, saying that 12 civilians who were arrested after the blast in Pirkoh were 'later killed in the custody of the paramilitary forces'... he said that 16 civilians also died in shelling and rocket attacks by paramilitary forces late Tuesday [01/10/2006] in Dera Bugti town and Loti area, while another was killed when he stepped on a landmine"; reportedly, "the death tolls given by both sides were impossible to verify independently"

Description: The Associated Press reported on 01/22/2006 that "Tribal militia and Pakistani security forces exchanged rocket and mortar fire in southwestern Pakistan, an official said Sunday [01/22/2006], leaving nine civilians dead and four soldiers wounded... about 500 rockets were fired in late Saturday's [01/21/2006] clash in Dera Bugti, a restive tribal town southeast of the provincial capital of Quetta in Baluchistan, local government administrator Abdul Samad Lasi said... rebels attacked an army base, a telephone exchange and government offices, Lasi added... the tribesmen are blamed for carrying out the attacks to press for more compensation for resources extracted in the sparsely populated region... they also oppose government plans to build new military garrisons... the government said it increased the number of troops in the area to protect gas fields... the rocket attack on the base housing the Frontier Corps -- responsible for security in the area -- damaged several buildings... the rebel assault also extended to several government buildings and a telephone exchange, knocking out Dera Bugti's communications link, Lasi said... it is not immediately clear how many rebels were involved in the attack... 'The Frontier Corps retaliated. The terrorists must have suffered casualties, but I do not have any details,' Lasi said by satellite phone... but a spokesman for a local tribal leader said nine civilians, including women and children were killed, while 14 others were injured... 'The Frontier Corps carried out rocket and mortar shelling into the town without any provocation, destroying two dozen homes and a Hindu temple,' spokesman Agha Shahid Bugti said... meanwhile, a human rights group said that security forces in Baluchistan have allegedly been responsible for "some" summary executions, deaths among civilians and "indiscriminate bombings" on civilian populations... 'There were alarming accounts of summary executions, some allegedly carried out by the paramilitary forces,' the independently run Human Rights Commission of Pakistan said in a report... 'HRCP received credible evidence that showed such killings had indeed taken place,' said the report that was issued in the capital Islamabad by its chairperson, Asma Jehangir... 'HRCP expressed grave concern over the fact that militants had placed land mines along roads, and appealed to all sides in the conflict to give up violence in favor of a negotiated resolution to the complex issues of the province,' said the report, compiled by group members who visited Baluchistan, including Jehangir... a Baluchistan government spokesman dismissed the report as 'one-sided' and denied allegations troops were involved in executions or firing on civilians"
Secondary.Source: "local [PAK] government administrator Abdul Samad Lasi", "a spokesman for a local tribal leader"

Description: The Associated Press reported on 3/11/2006 that Pakistani soldiers targeted a suspected militant hideout, killing about 30 militants according to army reports. However, residents and a "hard-line cleric" claims that the dead were noncombatant locals including women and children. An army general said the attack was launched after repeated clashes between militants and security forces. He is quoted, "We did that with full accuracy on authentic intelligence, and according to our information about 30 miscreants, who included foreigners, were killed." The army would not reveal the identity or nationality of those killed.  Two residents told an Associated Press reporter that they saw women and children among the dead. The cleric, also an opposition lawmaker condemned military actions during a session of the National Assembly. Another opposition leader was critical, but offered cooperation with the government through talks. The targeted compound was said to belong to a pro-Taliban cleric; it is unclear if he was at the location at the time of the attack.
Comments: The identity of the victims is contested in the report over whether or not the victims were militants or noncombatant locals. I marked the identity of the victims as unclear and marked their noncombatant status as contested.

Description: Government troops raided a gathering of suspected communist rebels on a farm in the central Philippines on Monday, killing 10 people and wounding five others, the military said.  Human rights activists and left-wing Rep. Satur Ocampo, however, denied the victims were rebels and accused the army of "massacring" farmers and political activists who were holding a vigil in a rice granary on central Leyte island.  On the other hand, Maj. Lope Dagoy, commander of the army's 19th Infantry Battalion, said a 45-minute firefight broke out after soldiers raided the rebel gathering on the farm. He said 10 guerrillas were killed, five wounded and 13 captured, while the military suffered no casualties.
Contesting.Source: Human rights activists and left-wing Rep. Satur Ocampo

Description: At least 100 people were killed in an attack by a rebel group on a town in Chad near its border with Sudan, Chadian officials said, the latest violence to erupt on the long, porous border between the two troubled nations.  A rebel group made up largely of deserters from Chad's army attacked the town of Adre early Sunday morning, Hourmadji Moussa Doumgor, Chad's minister of information, told Reuters.  He blamed the Sudanese government, saying it backed the rebel group, known as the Rally for Democracy and Liberty. The group is demanding that President Idriss Deby of Chad step down.  The attack comes as Chad struggles with a tide of financial, security and political woes. Mr. Deby seized power in 1990, ending a bloody civil war that had tortured the country on and off since its independence in 1960. While Mr. Deby is credited with bringing stability and, under pressure, multiparty democracy to Chad, divisions within the country's powerful military and the ruling Zaghawa tribe have undermined his authority.
Contesting.Source: Sudanese Foreign Ministry Spokesman Jamal Ibrahim
Comments: Chad has accused the RDL of being a militia used by the Sudanese government.  Sudan denies the claim.

Description: Eight nomadic herdsmen from Warsow, Somalia were apparently killed in "crossfire" during a January 8 air strike. Ethiopian forces have been accused of the air strike, but the Ethiopian prime minister and the US defense department deny this claim. Witnesses say the men were civilians.

Description: Ethiopian troops shot and killed five bystanders on May 30 after a land mine exploded as their convoy passed through the center of a western Somali town, police said. A remote-controlled land mine detonated in the town of Belet Weyne as the last vehicle in the convoy, a water tanker, passed. "Then the Ethiopians opened fire on civilians," police Col. Yusuf Aden told The Associated Press by telephone from Belet Weyne, 180 miles north of the capital, Mogadishu. "Five people, all of them passers-by, were killed and three others were wounded." The explosion rocked the town center, and huge plumes of smoke rose into the sky, said Ali Iid, a witness. The Ethiopian soldiers fired in all directions, then controlled movement at the site for 10 minutes before driving off, Iid told the AP by telephone.

A land-mine explosion in Mogadishu triggered a gun battle on June 19. Abdishakur Abdi Rahman, who was driving a bus that was passing as the blast went off, said Ethiopian troops opened fire on his vehicle after the blast. "The explosion occurred as the Ethiopians were passing us, then they opened fire on us," he said. "Two passengers were killed and my conductor was wounded." Haji Mohamud Igaal told the AP that his three teenage relatives and three others also were killed.
Six people were killed and ten injured on a minibus when they were attacked by Ethiopian soldiers who had just come under grenade attacks by insurgents.

Description: Eighty people died in 48 hours of fighting Friday that began when Ethiopian troops tried to retrieve the body of a soldier dragged through the streets of Mogadishu. Ethiopian troops fired tank shells in the north of the city, hitting a livestock market seen as a hotbed of insurgent supporters. Mogadishu's mayor accused members of the Islamic militant Shabab fighters of being responsible for the violence.
Comments: The article did not make clear how many of the 80 killed were civilians, nor did it clarify how many were killed by Ethiopian troops and how many by the Shabab fighters. The available information, however, seemed to indicate that most of those killed were in fact civilians. Further, the article did not discuss the death tolls for the individual events that led to the overall death toll for the day.

Description: Five people were killed during fighting in the Suga Holaha neighborhood of Mogadishu on Thursday during clashes between Ethiopian troops and pro-Islamist rebels. All of the victims were thought to be civilians, but the army says witnesses mistake insurgents for residents.

Five people were killed during fighting in the Yaqshid district of Mogadishu Friday during clashes between Ethiopian troops and pro-Islamist rebels. All of the victims were thought to be civilians, but the army says witnesses mistake insurgents for residents.

Insurgents armed with rocket-propelled grenades and assault rifles attacked an Ethiopian army base in northern Mogadishu, triggering a deadly nighttime clash that sent stray mortar rounds crashing into homes, residents and witnesses said Sunday. At least five Somalis were killed and eight wounded in the crossfire, they said.

A mortar round fired during fighting between Somali insurgents and Ethiopian troops killed a mother and her five young children in the capital Mogadishu, a witness and a relative said. Insurgents attacked bases of Ethiopian troops in the south of the capital with mortars and the Ethiopians fired back, said neighbor Mostaf Abdi Ahmed. About 30 mortar rounds were fired, he said.

Islamic militants firing rockets and mortars clashed with Somali troops and their Ethiopian allies in fighting that killed at least 17 civilians and two Ethiopian soldiers in the capital, witnesses said Tuesday. The fighting occurred late Monday as Somali and Ethiopian troops conducted house-to-house searches in Mogadishu's northern Hiliwa district, traditional elder Mohamud Haji Nur said. Insurgents also fired mortars and rocket-propelled grenades at a former pasta factory where the Ethiopians have a military base. The Ethiopians responded with artillery shells that slammed into nearby residential areas, Nur said.
Comments: Two Ethiopian soldiers died in the clashes as well.

Description: Insurgents fired machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades at Somali soldiers on patrol Saturday in the southern part of Mogadishu, said Mumin Mohamed Sahal and Muse Abdulle Hassan, who separately witnessed the fighting. Ethiopian soldiers, who are supporting the Somali government, later joined in. "I saw the dead bodies of five civilians and a government soldier in different places in our village," Hassan told The Associated Press on phone.Doctors at Mogadishu hospitals said they were treating at least 13 civilians wounded in Saturday's violence.

Mortar strikes on the Bakara Market killed and injured a number of civilians on Saturday, 30 March, 2008.  Ethiopian soldiers guarding President Abdullah Yusuf and Ethiopian Foreign Minister Seyoum Mesfin began launching shells into Bakara Market after Islamist insurgents attacked the Presidential Palace where the two men were meeting.  At least 17 people in the market were killed, but a leader of the business community in Bakara Market said 28 had been killed, including traders, customers and porters.
Contesting.Source: Leader of business community in Bakara
Comments: Estimates of numbers killed ranged from at least 17 to 28 persons.

Description: Militias allied to the Somali government recaptured a southern port from Islamists on Tuesday, as the death toll from an upsurge of fighting in recent days rose to nearly 100, witnesses said. A spokesman for the Islamic Courts, Sheikh Ibrahim Suley, said the real death toll from the weekend violence in Mogadishu was much higher, and talks with the government had consequently been postponed indefinitely. "The Ethiopians killed around 200 people and kidnapped 160 others including 41 Koranic students ... We will continue fighting the Ethiopians and those under the protection of their tanks. We call on them to repent," Suley told Reuters.
Contesting.Source: A spokesman for the Islamic Courts, Sheikh Ibrahim Suley

Description: Ethiopia rejected on Thursday accusations by Amnesty International that its soldiers killed 21 people at a Somali mosque as "lies" and "propaganda". The rights group said on Wednesday the soldiers, stationed in Somalia to bolster the interim government, had also captured dozens of children in a raid on the Al Hidaaya mosque earlier this week during operations against Islamist insurgents. It said an imam and several Islamic scholars were among the dead, and that seven victims had their throats slit. "Amnesty's allegations are unsubstantiated lies and propaganda that they received from Islamic groups in Somalia. Ethiopia has never been involved in such incidents," said Information Ministry spokesman Zemedkun Tekle. Bereket Simon, President Meles Zenawi's special adviser, also criticised the report, noting the human rights group has no presence in Somalia. "It is gathering hearsay and accusing Ethiopia based on false information." In a statement, U.N. humanitarian chief John Holmes urged protection for civilians and criticised the mosque raid. "He also strongly condemned the brutal killings that occurred on 20 April at Al Hidaaya mosque in Heliwaa district of Mogadishu, where women and children were present," said a statement from his New York office.

Ethiopian troops allied to Somalia's shaky government opened fire on civilians in a street in southwestern Somalia, killing 13 on Wednesday after an explosion there killed two soldiers, witnesses said.  Witness Mohamud Ahmed Nur said an explosion apparently caused by a remote-controlled land mine killed the two Ethiopian troops, who were patrolling the town of Baidoa.The soldiers, he said, then opened fire in all directions, killing at least 10 civilian passers-by outright. Mohamed Hussein Diriye, a doctor at the town's main hospital, said three more people died later of their injuries and that seven others were still being treated at the hospital, he said. In the capital Mogadishu, a Ethiopian military commander denied that his troops had opened fire, saying the bomb blast against the Ethiopia water truck was responsible for killing at least 17 civilians and one of his soldiers.
Primary.Source: Associated Press and Agence France Presse

Description: At least five demonstrators were killed Monday when Somali security forces fired at crowds protesting rising food prices in the capital Mogadishu, witnesses said.  "Police opened fire at civilians who were closing in on a police station (and) killed two demonstrators, including a young boy in Dharkiley area," Farah Mohamed Abdi told AFP. Another witness, Osman Mukhtar, said police shot two other civilians at a checkpoint in the Waberi area when they responded to grenade attack, bringing the total death toll to five from the demonstrations after another death was reported earlier. "Several people were wounded in Waberi area," Mukhtar added.

Some 23 were killed late Wednesday near the village of Garsani, some 300 kilometres (180 miles) north of Mogadishu, when insurgents ambushed an Ethiopian military convoy. Several witnesses said at least 13 civilians and eight Ethiopian soldiers had been killed in the fighting, while the insurgents admitted to losing two fighters in the battle. "The fighting was so heavy and our holy warriors with the help of Allah won a huge victory," Sheikh Abdirahin Ise, an Islamist spokesman told AFP. "In return they (Ethiopians) killed pastoralists who were near the fighting zone," he added.

Ethiopian forces late Wednesday killed at least 12 nomads in Walaweyne, about 90 kilometres (55 miles) east of Mogadishu, bringing the death toll to 35. Those nomads were setting up their makeshift camp in Almore village when they were killed by Ethiopia forces who had been ambushed by insurgents on a nearby road," Sheikh Mohamed Addow, another elder. "The Ethiopians slit throats of some people," he added. Another elder, Ali Omar confirmed the death toll said the bodies were being prepared for burial.
